story:
Summary

Aiken high school is a high needs urban high school in Cincinnati, OH. Last year, we launched a fundraising campaign for disposable lab safety gear, chemicals, and durable lab equipment for urban high school students. We were able to raise roughly 20% of our goal, and, oh, what we did with that money, my friends. We launched a student-led initiative to remediate a piece of urban wasteland owned by the school - a parcel that had been abandoned for the better part of a decade. In that time, it had become inaccessible due to the construction of new buildings around it and illegal dumping.  After climbing down into the area by chance, the science club, together with the AP environmental science class, designed and constructed a 250 ft environmentally sensitive footpath to make the site accessible, began construction on 400 square feet of gravity-watered gardens, cleared out two tons of trash, reopened a creek, removed invasive species, conducted an extensive water and soil testing program over 60 acres,  remediated a wetland, and planted a prairie. 
This year, we are asking for your help again so that we can continue our work. For those that generously donated last year, and for those who might be able to do so for the first time, here is what we did with last year's donations.

Science for a better world

This is the science club (minus four members). We are standing in front of a steep, overgrown hill.  In Fall 2014, we climbed down it. 


This is what that slope was like in September 2014  - steep, dangerous due to fallen and dead trees, poison ivy, and overwhelmed with invasive species. 

Um, so what? But what was down there at the bottom were 60+ acres of school property formerly the site of a long out-of-use athletic facility that had been more recently used as a construction debris dump and combined sewage overflow basin for the nearby heavily polluted Mill Creek.  The original district plan, dependent on a rebuild of the sewer system, was to sell the property to the electric company to build a power plant. 

This had not happened in part because the federally mandated sewer plan was put on hold. In addition, the parcel became completely inaccessible by road when the old school buildings were demolished and new ones built. During the demolition and construction phase, everyone, from the construction firms to private individuals, dumped into the area.  

Hard to picture? Here is a photo of us at the base of the slope removing invasive plants in the early spring - you get a lot of die-back in our vegetation zone. What you see in the background isn't really as natural it seems - most of that "meadow" is composed heavy construction debris (mostly concrete and rebar) covered with thin layer of soil and grass planted by the sewer company. 


We decided to build an environmentally sensitive path down the slope to open up the area for remediation. The students precisely calculated the quantity of untreated sand, gravel, and landscape timbers we would need. They did all of the construction.

We spent the rest of the fall and winter, including weekends and school breaks, clearing the location of the path of trash and debris. We completed the path in May, in the rain, in one day, with the help of a local church that loaned us a four-wheeler with a grader attachment. Can you feel the mud?


This was the result

Middle section


In addition to this engineering and construction project, we spent several days per week throughout the school year designing and implementing an extensive testing program to determine the toxicity of the water and soil throughout the site. We were particularly interested in very overgrown area which we identified as the bed of the original creek through the parcel, now used for sewage overflow during periods of heavy rain. This is what we were up against there. This is an interesting photo because, if you look behind the student in the orange shirt, you can see the concrete that makes up  the "hill" behind her poking through the grass. 


Water and soil testing over 60 acres is not for the fainthearted. The bacterial contamination was so extreme in some areas that we had to call out the sewer department for emergency remediation. There was also extensive contamination with heavy metals, primarily, we think, from local companies dumping toxic materials like paint, car parts, tires, and motor oil. 


Environmental science - most of it really happens indoors in the lab.



Once we determined the relative safety of the water running into the old creek bed, we decided to build gravity-watered garden beds. A wetland opened up by our trash removal ran along one side of the garden site, which will provide a wealth of opportunities for investigating the effect of raised gardens on local aquatic ecosystems. Below you can see the garden beds under construction.


Simultaneously, we ran a hydroponics study in the classroom (yes, simultaneously with all-the-above - we were busy) to determine which plants were most likely to tolerate the high nitrogen/high phosphorus content of the soil, which was hydrated by run off from the school area and the (artificially-controlled) overflow of the creek bed. Two students worked on the hydroponics project every day for four months.



What We Need 

By the end of the year, we had reached  half of our goals. The path was built and the remediation area was now accessible again. We had come up with protocols for testing soil and water over a large area, and our hydroponics technique was perfected. We had built the garden beds, but the 100-year rain of the early summer washed away the framing before we could finish them. We think we know how to engineer for that possibility now.  We were able to re-seed the area cleared of invasive species with local (prairie) plants, but were not able to do this for more than a third of the site due to timing and funding. 

Large parts of the site still need our help. Invasive species are still a problem, as is illegal dumping.  We hope to expand our access path to connect with a parks department wildlife conservation area path which we have heard is up the northeast slope of the basin, but which we have not yet located. Given the history of contamination, our water and soil testing protocol needs to be ongoing if we are going to continue to safely work on the site at all. The students have learned authentic environmental science and laboratory techniques, but this, and so much more, remains out of our reach due to our limited resources.  The resources we need will be used not just by our environmental science program, but by  all of our science classes as we continue to integrate our field work into real world, project-based science for all our students.

Our greatest need remains safety gear and other single use or non-durable equipment that needs to be bought every year: gloves, aprons, disinfecting materials, pipettes, bins, duct tape, chemicals, reaction plates, and test kits. 

We also very badly need  rubber boots ("Wellies") for about twenty students in a range of sizes since our students do not have more than one or two pairs of shoes, and the outdoor work is hard on footwear. Our estimate for non-durable equipment plus (re-usable) work clothing and footwear is $2,500

We also badly need permanent lab equipment, particularly microscopes. The entire high school is still getting by with three, two of which are constantly on the repair bench, and only one of which is capable of the resolution needed to count microorganisms in a water sample. It also increasingly clear, given the level of bacterial contamination at our testing sites, that we cannot continue our soil and water testing without an autoclave. Another good stereoscopic microscope plus a desktop autoclave would cost over $2000.

Our school continues to have no budget for materials needed on the scale of our professional-level environmental science work.   We have just $250 in our lab safety budget from the district. 


The Impact

We believe our work is important. Our goal is to involve the entire Cincinnati Public School district in large scale urban wasteland remediation, with Aiken teachers and Aiken students providing generational support. Cincinnati is a rust belt town with large tracts of abandoned land. We are making our difference at Aiken and want to share our knowledge with the rest of the city.  When Aiken students and other visitors walk down the path into an area once known primarily as a good place to dump old car parts, the potential of urban wasteland throughout the city becomes real.  



Risks & Challenges

We continue to struggle with fundraising. Many local groups will not contribute to organizations that do not raise a large percentage of the overall project funding. We would love to be at a funding level where we could apply for larger grants. Outside of our Indiegogo campaign last year, we were able to raise just $500 more through a t-shirt campaign and from the church that helped us with the path construction. We need to do more in this regard. Our students also struggle under the burden of poverty, homelessness, and low expectations. Several of our original group had to drop out of our project and leave school early to earn money for their families. We still consider them to be with us in spirit, falcons (we are the Aiken falcons) in their natural habitat.


What you get

A better world. There are also a few perks with your donation, but the better world part is real.
story_txt:
Summary
Aiken high school is a high needs urban high school in Cincinnati, OH. Last year, we launched a fundraising campaign for disposable lab safety gear, chemicals, and durable lab equipment for urban high school students. We were able to raise roughly 20% of our goal, and, oh, what we did with that money, my friends. We launched a student-led initiative to remediate a piece of urban wasteland owned by the school - a parcel that had been abandoned for the better part of a decade. In that time, it had become inaccessible due to the construction of new buildings around it and illegal dumping.  After climbing down into the area by chance, the science club, together with the AP environmental science class, designed and constructed a 250 ft environmentally sensitive footpath to make the site accessible, began construction on 400 square feet of gravity-watered gardens, cleared out two tons of trash, reopened a creek, removed invasive species, conducted an extensive water and soil testing program over 60 acres,  remediated a wetland, and planted a prairie. 
This year, we are asking for your help again so that we can continue our work. For those that generously donated last year, and for those who might be able to do so for the first time, here is what we did with last year's donations.

Science for a better world
This is the science club (minus four members). We are standing in front of a steep, overgrown hill.  In Fall 2014, we climbed down it. 




This is what that slope was like in September 2014  - steep, dangerous due to fallen and dead trees, poison ivy, and overwhelmed with invasive species. 


Um, so what? But what was down there at the bottom were 60+ acres of school property formerly the site of a long out-of-use athletic facility that had been more recently used as a construction debris dump and combined sewage overflow basin for the nearby heavily polluted Mill Creek.  The original district plan, dependent on a rebuild of the sewer system, was to sell the property to the electric company to build a power plant. 
This had not happened in part because the federally mandated sewer plan was put on hold. In addition, the parcel became completely inaccessible by road when the old school buildings were demolished and new ones built. During the demolition and construction phase, everyone, from the construction firms to private individuals, dumped into the area.  
Hard to picture? Here is a photo of us at the base of the slope removing invasive plants in the early spring - you get a lot of die-back in our vegetation zone. What you see in the background isn't really as natural it seems - most of that "meadow" is composed heavy construction debris (mostly concrete and rebar) covered with thin layer of soil and grass planted by the sewer company. 


We decided to build an environmentally sensitive path down the slope to open up the area for remediation. The students precisely calculated the quantity of untreated sand, gravel, and landscape timbers we would need. They did all of the construction.

We spent the rest of the fall and winter, including weekends and school breaks, clearing the location of the path of trash and debris. We completed the path in May, in the rain, in one day, with the help of a local church that loaned us a four-wheeler with a grader attachment. Can you feel the mud?


This was the result
Middle section


In addition to this engineering and construction project, we spent several days per week throughout the school year designing and implementing an extensive testing program to determine the toxicity of the water and soil throughout the site. We were particularly interested in very overgrown area which we identified as the bed of the original creek through the parcel, now used for sewage overflow during periods of heavy rain. This is what we were up against there. This is an interesting photo because, if you look behind the student in the orange shirt, you can see the concrete that makes up  the "hill" behind her poking through the grass. 


Water and soil testing over 60 acres is not for the fainthearted. The bacterial contamination was so extreme in some areas that we had to call out the sewer department for emergency remediation. There was also extensive contamination with heavy metals, primarily, we think, from local companies dumping toxic materials like paint, car parts, tires, and motor oil. 
Environmental science - most of it really happens indoors in the lab.





Once we determined the relative safety of the water running into the old creek bed, we decided to build gravity-watered garden beds. A wetland opened up by our trash removal ran along one side of the garden site, which will provide a wealth of opportunities for investigating the effect of raised gardens on local aquatic ecosystems. Below you can see the garden beds under construction.



Simultaneously, we ran a hydroponics study in the classroom (yes, simultaneously with all-the-above - we were busy) to determine which plants were most likely to tolerate the high nitrogen/high phosphorus content of the soil, which was hydrated by run off from the school area and the (artificially-controlled) overflow of the creek bed. Two students worked on the hydroponics project every day for four months.







What We Need 

 By the end of the year, we had reached  half of our goals. The path was built and the remediation area was now accessible again. We had come up with protocols for testing soil and water over a large area, and our hydroponics technique was perfected. We had built the garden beds, but the 100-year rain of the early summer washed away the framing before we could finish them. We think we know how to engineer for that possibility now.  We were able to re-seed the area cleared of invasive species with local (prairie) plants, but were not able to do this for more than a third of the site due to timing and funding. 
Large parts of the site still need our help. Invasive species are still a problem, as is illegal dumping.  We hope to expand our access path to connect with a parks department wildlife conservation area path which we have heard is up the northeast slope of the basin, but which we have not yet located. Given the history of contamination, our water and soil testing protocol needs to be ongoing if we are going to continue to safely work on the site at all. The students have learned authentic environmental science and laboratory techniques, but this, and so much more, remains out of our reach due to our limited resources.  The resources we need will be used not just by our environmental science program, but by  all of our science classes as we continue to integrate our field work into real world, project-based science for all our students. Our greatest need remains safety gear and other single use or non-durable equipment that needs to be bought every year: gloves, aprons, disinfecting materials, pipettes, bins, duct tape, chemicals, reaction plates, and test kits. 
We also very badly need  rubber boots ("Wellies") for about twenty students in a range of sizes since our students do not have more than one or two pairs of shoes, and the outdoor work is hard on footwear. Our estimate for non-durable equipment plus (re-usable) work clothing and footwear is $2,500
We also badly need permanent lab equipment, particularly microscopes. The entire high school is still getting by with three, two of which are constantly on the repair bench, and only one of which is capable of the resolution needed to count microorganisms in a water sample. It also increasingly clear, given the level of bacterial contamination at our testing sites, that we cannot continue our soil and water testing without an autoclave. Another good stereoscopic microscope plus a desktop autoclave would cost over $2000.
Our school continues to have no budget for materials needed on the scale of our professional-level environmental science work.   We have just $250 in our lab safety budget from the district. 
    
The Impact We believe our work is important. Our goal is to involve the entire Cincinnati Public School district in large scale urban wasteland remediation, with Aiken teachers and Aiken students providing generational support. Cincinnati is a rust belt town with large tracts of abandoned land. We are making our difference at Aiken and want to share our knowledge with the rest of the city.  When Aiken students and other visitors walk down the path into an area once known primarily as a good place to dump old car parts, the potential of urban wasteland throughout the city becomes real.  



    Risks & Challenges We continue to struggle with fundraising. Many local groups will not contribute to organizations that do not raise a large percentage of the overall project funding. We would love to be at a funding level where we could apply for larger grants. Outside of our Indiegogo campaign last year, we were able to raise just $500 more through a t-shirt campaign and from the church that helped us with the path construction. We need to do more in this regard. Our students also struggle under the burden of poverty, homelessness, and low expectations. Several of our original group had to drop out of our project and leave school early to earn money for their families. We still consider them to be with us in spirit, falcons (we are the Aiken falcons) in their natural habitat.




What you get
A better world. There are also a few perks with your donation, but the better world part is real.

story:
In first of November 2015 the towns of (Mhein, Hwarein, Alhadath, AlGhanthar) located in Eastern Homs Countryside were attacked by ISIS troops located in nearby AlQaryatin town … beside the Russian bombing to the area which cased in mass evacuation for local residents,

beside 2800 IDP families from AlQaryatin who were located in Mhein.

The local families moved to ISIS controlled areas (AlQaryatin, Khneis, AlSwaneh, Tadmur – Palmyra – AlTabaka, AlRaqa,..) in attempt to flee the bombing threatened areas.

The Russian airstrikes targeted the new areas that the families fled to which caused tens of casualties (dead and wounded), so the families moved again to the liberated areas -opposition controlled areas-  (Idleb countryside, western Aleppo countryside) going through almost 1000KM, despite the difficulties and the lack of transportation vehicles and ISIS barriers, almost 800 families made it to  the Opposition controlled areas of (AlDana, Sarmada, Toqad, Kafarnaha, Deir Hassan, Harim, Silqeen, Tal Adi), another 1000 are still in ISIS controlled areas trying to relocate to these areas.

Teams provided transportation vehicles to move the families to safer opposition controlled areas, a committee of local IDPs from the targeted areas provides also transportation vehicles to move the families – funded by expats from these areas - .

The lack of tenancy houses in these areas (that the families relocate to ) - because of the crises of Aleppo southern countryside IDPs – creates emergency urge to host IDP families in a camp.

we put a plan to build a camp on 2 phases (500 families each) tents already provided by the UN , work already started in 22/11/2015 :

story:
Short Summary

My name is James Faucette and I’m asking for your support of my dream to help the advancement of Maryland youth, starting in P.G. County. To give a little a background; I was born in Calvert County, Maryland and taken by CPS at 3 because my mother tried to burn down the house while my brother and I were in it, moved from foster home to be eventually adopted at 9. Approximately 3 years later, my parents separated and I was forced to move with my mom.  Going through a struggle financially, emotionally and feeling invisible, I made dumb decisions and became an "at-risk" youth.  I always had dreams of making music and performing arts but my parents were the type that believed there was no money in it, subsequently they shut down my dreams early. There was no opportunity for me to express my artistic side and essentially I was forced to survive in my environment at home and the streets. My survival tactics in 2005 led me to a stern consequence I’ll never regret and am able to embrace NOW.   I have been a returning citizen since 2008 and during that time away I reflected on “if things were different in my life, how would it have effected my life”? Ever since that revelation, I have been compelled to dedicate my life to helping kids and youth that maybe in a similar position, and I don’t want them to lose their life or make malign choices because they feel there is no other option and/or because they also feel invincible.

My program is called M.A.Y.B.E (Men Assisting Young Brothers to Excel) and my focus is helping at risk youth through mentor-ship and changing lifestyles. My business slogan is “Prevention is better than Punishment”.  As a youth these days,“trying to fit in” is paramount and I believe is a cause for the youth delinquency and/or incarceration rate increasing.Thank you so much for your time and any donation "BIG or small" to help bring my dream to fruition is greatly appreciated!!!



What We Need

I have set a goal of $30,000 to cover "start- up" costs but my dream is bigger; so the more donated, the bigger the impact of possibilities for "at-risk" and disenfranchised youth in Maryland. Below is a list of where the donations will be allocated to:
  • 20,000 to cover the lease of the building for 12 months
  • 3,000 to cover gov't fees, legal fees, installation fees (i.e. phone, internet, )
  • 3,000 to cover stationary and Marketing (website,business cards, flyers, community day to promote the Organization)
  • 4,000 to cover the items needed inside building (computers, printer, chairs, desks, posters, toiletries(paper towels, toilet paper) and refrigerator/freezer.


The Impact

Over the years the amount of juveniles in the Juvenile Justice Department has catapulted to alarming numbers. Reading this campaign is the first step in helping to make a change. Making a donation not only shows the youth that people do care and are willing to support them, but also shows DREAMS can be accomplished if you put God first and put your all into it.

  • Children just want to know that someone cares when they feel invisible and your donation shows support
  • As an "at-risk" youth myself I know internally how it feels to be that lost child and I  have assisted young men and women find purpose and assist them to open perspective to a bigger world through my story.
  • This organization will provide a positive male role model and give youth an opportunity to be in a safe haven and give them a positive outlet opposed to the streets and drugs

Risks & Challenges

 There are a few challenges with opening a non-profit, one being sustainability. Secondly, ideally I want to save every child that comes through the program but I know that will be unlikely, hence the title of MAYBE! With constant support and workshops I believe this program will either change their lives or at least open their mind to change.

  • I am working with Maryland Juvenile Justice Department about attaining the kids in local school districts that are delinquent and also youth that are on probation.
  • As the program grows there will be more fundraisers and incentives i will send to donators.and supporters.

Other Ways You Can Help

Some people just can't contribute, but that doesn't mean YOU can't help:

  • Support and Promotion is as imperative as obtaining a donation.
  • NO amount is too small (1,000 people that donate 5$ is the same as 2 people donating 2500$)
  • Share the link to "OUR" fundraiser, your support solely makes it "OURS"

THANK YOU AND GOD BLESS!!!!

story:
HELP POWER NEPAL:

DONATE SOLAR LANTERNS AND MOBILE PHONE CHARGERS TO SURVIVORS OF THE NEPAL EARTHQUAKE

  • After the devastating 7.8 magnitude earthquake and aftershocks felt in Nepal , hundreds of thousands of Nepalis desperately need access to power and light, essential for night-time security and staying in touch with their loved ones.

  • Greenlight Planet has teamed up with World Vision International to get Sun King™ solar lanterns and mobile phone chargers to families devastated by the earthquake and we need your help.

  • For $19, you’ll provide one family with a Sun King™ solar lantern and mobile phone charger, enabling them to move about safely after dark and stay connected with their loved ones. 100 percent of the funds raised will go towards providing and distributing Sun King lanterns to those in need.

What We Need & What You Get:

Breakdown of the Campaign:

  • Our goal is to raise $30,000 to send 1,515 solar lights to Nepal with World Vision. These lights will be distributed to earthquake survivors.

  • By donating $19, you’ll provide a family with a light and mobile phone charger. For $38 dollars, you'll provide for two families, for $57 you'll provide for 3 families and so on and so forth.

  • If we don't reach our goal, lights will still be sent to Nepal, but the total amount will be less. We feel that providing close to 1,500 families with lights and mobile charging is a small feat and ultimately we hope to provide more than this.

The Impact:

  • Greenlight Planet has teamed up with World Vision, an organization with a proven track record in humanitarian and disaster relief. World Vision is dedicated to working with children, families and their communities worldwide to reach their full potential by tackling poverty and injustice.  

  • Greenlight Planet regularly works with humanitarian groups that need easily deployed, clean and reliable energy to operate where there is little to no infrastructure. We take tremendous pride in our ability to act quickly and effectively in the event of any disaster.

  • With warehouses spread across the globe, Greenlight Planet is ready to ship at any time and can rush bulk shipments for disaster relief to any region of the globe.

  • We are trusted partners of the United Nations, MFI’s, NGO’s and governments around the world.

  • Greenlight Planet ranks in the top 10 percent among social businesses, has a five-star rating from the Global Impact Investing Rating System (GIIRS) and two B Corp awards.

story:
“Every man lives in two realms: the internal and the external." -Martin Luther King Jr.

When we are faced with obstacles in our everyday life we can categorize them into two basic sections. Internal and external. External obstacles are often things we cannot control naturally causing us to deal with them head on or avoid them all together. Internal obstacles are often ideas or thoughts we may have that hold us back. We sometimes second guess ourselves and internally criticize who we are or what situation we may be in which can wear any human down. This thought process can at times be the biggest obstacle. This is where the lessons and tools that the Thriving Changemakers summit offers can help.

I have worked in many different fields including an under-privileged nursing home and fundraising for an environmental non-profit. These careers both inspired me to connect with people and I began to feel that my calling was to connect and reach out to humanity. I have continued to work towards a career in the humanitarian field for a few years now and have been involved in group meetings about earth-ships (Vahalla Colorado). I also learned of a ministry group that sponsored programs in Ethiopa and Nigeria teaching locals of the importance of cleaning and storing water. It was an interesting experience to here from the African pastors who were there telling stories of how they lived and I learned a lot from meeting with these groups who discussed their plans for the future. Bringing sustainable living practices like these over seas benefits not only those living there now, but will continue to help families for decades to come.

Over the past years I’ve explored much of the continental US and worked in these various fields. In my years of travels I have learned much about myself and my vision for working in the sustainable living field. With an exponentially growing world population our generation, and those to come, will need to utilize the remaining resources we have left on the planet to the fullest extent. My goal is to one day work helping build, maintain, and promote sustainable living through Earthship Biotecture while using renewable energy and new technologies that will sustain us into the future. Whether Internationally or here in America setting up communities for success is the right thing to do.

To achieve this goal I am planning on attending the Thriving Changemakers summit this October to learn the right tools for navigating this long road. This summit includes resilience and positivity training that are unparalleled anywhere else. This course will help steady the compass of my journey and I am extremely excited for the opportunity to attend.

Here’s how you can help me accomplish this:

To be successful in the sustainable living field and to really make a difference to the environment and beneficial to humanity I know I need to establish my personal empowerment tools. The Thriving Change-makers Summit is a program that will not only help shape my thinking in a way that is beneficial to achieving my dreams, but also inspire me to really think about what direction the future may hold. I want to do this to be able to connect to a network of other thriving changemakers who really want to make change happen in our world.

Will you help contribute to my Tuition? I am raising $1500 to make it all happen.

story:
This year I was accepted into the Agriculture, Food, and Environment program at Tufts University where I will pursue my Master's Degree! This represents the crystallization of the career that I've been building for the last 5-6 years through work and volunteer experience. 

I am so excited for this next step, but I am also trepidatious about the financial challenge this opportunity presents. When I finish school, I will be pursuing modest-salaried jobs with non-profit organizations, and with debt still looming from my undergraduate studies, added debt from graduate school will impact my life for decades. That is why I am seeking as many alternate sources of funding for my education as possible. I hope you will consider donating or sharing this campaign with someone who might wish to invest in my future and the sustainable food future I hope to contribute to!

$2,000 would cover the cost of books and supplies and transportation in Boston, as estimated by Tufts' Financial Aid Office. Please help me cover these basics! If 100 people give $20, I will reach my goal! 

I am so grateful to the people I've learned from and worked with over the years. My friends and colleagues have helped me see the path to a fulfilling career that contributes positively to the world. Here are some of the experiences that have shaped my career and perspective:

Working at Tantre Farm in 2010 was a turning point in my path that turned my curiosity with agriculture and food into a true passion. All three of my farmer friends pictured above have gone on to have farming businesses/jobs of their own.

While helping to manage the Ann Arbor Farmers Market, I was inspired by the tenacity of small farmers and food business owners, and I started to better understand the many challenges they face. The Brinery and Seeley Farm (featured above) are now successful local businesses and I hope to see more businesses like theirs thrive!

This is me making green smoothies for 5th and 6th graders from local apples and kale. In 2013, I started as a Farm to School Coordinator and helped 6 schools buy food from local farmers and introduce students to more healthy, local food. 

In 2014, I helped a school garden grow food for their cafeteria and sustain their school garden program. Here's one of the harvests in the garden just before being delivered to the school cafeteria .

In 2014, I worked on policy advocacy around Farm Bill implementation for the National Sustainable Agriculture Coalition. This is one of our colleagues sharing the reason he cares about local food for our communications campaign in front of the Michigan state capital during Farmers Market at the Capital.
 
I want to continue to explore ways to improve the food system through avenues such as these, and grad school will help me do that! I would be eternally grateful for your contribution to help me continue this momentum. THANK YOU!!
story_txt:
This year I was accepted into the Agriculture, Food, and Environment program at Tufts University where I will pursue my Master's Degree! This represents the crystallization of the career that I've been building for the last 5-6 years through work and volunteer experience. I am so excited for this next step, but I am also trepidatious about the financial challenge this opportunity presents. When I finish school, I will be pursuing modest-salaried jobs with non-profit organizations, and with debt still looming from my undergraduate studies, added debt from graduate school will impact my life for decades. That is why I am seeking as many alternate sources of funding for my education as possible. I hope you will consider donating or sharing this campaign with someone who might wish to invest in my future and the sustainable food future I hope to contribute to! $2,000 would cover the cost of books and supplies and transportation in Boston, as estimated by Tufts' Financial Aid Office. Please help me cover these basics! If 100 people give $20, I will reach my goal! I am so grateful to the people I've learned from and worked with over the years. Here's one of the harvests in the garden just before being delivered to the school cafeteria .

story:
Short Summary

 

This is me: I'm a student at the University of York, studying a BSc in Bioarchaeology, and have volunteered to be part of the SKIP (Students for Kids International Project) scheme that the university runs.

The project means spending 11 days in Tanzania, educating nursery and secondary school children. More specifically, this is what I will be doing: 

I would really like to go and participate in all of the above :D

What I Need

The cost of the trip will be around £1,750. Usually I would fundraise for myself, but I have to fundraise for the SKIP Project itself, rather than just my place. I will be possibly participating in 10k runs, bake sales - anything that is organised. Here is a full breakdown of expenditures for the trip:

If I can not go, for any reason, I WILL REFUND everyone that has donated to me. I will be contributing myself; excess from the group fundraising and saving up.

The Impact

The most important part of the trip will be educating the older children on the more serious matters, such as HIV awareness; I consider topics of that nature of the most importance, and would educate all of the countries that needed aid if I could.

This is not the first trip like this that I have participated in: in 2010, I took part in the 12th Macau International Dance Festival and also had to teach children then. Even though I was 14, I remained committed to the gruelling itinerary.

Risks & Challenges

My biggest challenge here will be fundraising the money itself: SKIP is a very organised program and have been doing projects like this since 2008.

Other Ways You Can Help

You can donate by card or Paypal :) If you cannot donate, you could share the link to this project; that would be a HUGE help. I am grateful for anything that may be donated.

Thank you for your time :)

story:
Bref résumé  

L’ONG Cavoequiva est une organisation non gouvernementale créée le 23 mars 2003 dont la mission essentielle est de promouvoir le bien-être et la défense des droits de l’Homme et en particulier ceux de l’Enfant et de la Femme à Abidjan, Côte d'Ivoire.

LA SITUATION ACTUELLE

L'ONG s'occupe d'accueillir des enfants et des jeunes filles en situation de vulnérabilité suite à des abus  multiples.

La majorité des filles recueillies ont été confiées par leur famille à des tutrices ou tuteurs pour être scolarisées et mises en apprentissage. Cependant, celles-ci  sont placées comme servantes, vendeuses d’eau, nounous, etc. et sont exploitées et/ou maltraitées par des  patrons sans scrupule. Elles quittent donc  le cadre familial de l'exploiteur et se retrouvent  à la rue.

Une fois là, elles doivent survivre, sans abri et sans la protection d’une famille. Elles deviennent vulnérables à toutes sortes de risques tels que le viol dans les marchés gares routières et  bidonvilles, le travail précaire, la consommation de drogues ou la prostitution de survie. Cette dernière les expose alors au VIH /sida et/ou à des grossesses précoces et indésirées.

LES ACTIONS DE L'ONG

    Face à cette situation de vulnérabilité des enfants et jeunes filles, l'ONG Cavoequiva :

1. a mis en place un Centre de Transit Communautaire à Abidjan  qui assure :

  • un hébergement temporaire (3 mois en moyenne)
  • une prise en charge holistique (aide psychosociale, sanitaire, alimentaire, hygiénique, vestimentaire,  alphabétisation, apprentissage de métiers, activités culturelles...)

  2. apporte des solutions durables aux problèmes des mineures victimes d’exploitation par :

  • des sessions de compétences de vie pour développer leur confiance en soi, leur estime de soi et leur affirmation de soi
  • des ateliers d'apprentissage professionnel en couture, pâtisserie, cuisine, art floral, crochet...
  • des actions de sensibilisation de proximité de jour et de nuit, et de masse dans les marchés, gares routières de la commune d'Adjamé 
  • la recherche des familles, la médiation et la réunification familiale des enfants.

LES DIFFICULTÉS

L’ONG reçoit en moyenne cinq filles par semaine référées par la Sous-Direction de la Police Criminelle, les Brigades de gendarmerie, les Centres Sociaux, la communauté, l'ONUDC et l'ONUCI, etc.

Aujourd'hui, l’ONG ne dispose pas de capacité suffisante pour l’accueil des pensionnaires dont le nombre croît de jour en jour. Les infrastructures actuelles sont trop exiguës et ne répondent plus aux besoins de prise en charge des pensionnaires : insuffisance des toilettes, de salles d’eau, de dortoirs, manque de salles de jeux et de réfectoires.

Elle héberge à ce jour 50 enfants et jeunes filles pour une capacité initiale de 16 pensionnaires.

Ce dont nous avons besoin et ce que vous obtenez

L'ONG Cavoequiva initie le projet de réhabilitation et d'agrandissement du Centre de Transit Communautaire afin d'augmenter ses capacités d'accueil à 48 pensionnaires  en y adjoignant toutes les commodités à même de leur assurer des conditions de vie et d'hygiène de bonne qualité.

Cela permettra non seulement d'offrir un environnement sécurisé et bienveillant aux enfants et aux jeunes filles maltraitées le temps du séjour dans le centre de Transit (3 mois en moyenne) ; leur donnant ainsi la possibilité de quitter l'univers dangereux de la rue mais aussi de leur fournir un cadre à même de les aider dans la construction de leur personnalité et de leur vie le temps de faire la recherche, la médiation et la réunification familiale.

Pour ce faire, nous avons besoin d'un montant de 200 000 $ qui va permettre de réhabiliter le centre qui est actuellement une maison basse en un immeuble d'un étage comprenant l'ensemble des services : salle de soins , dortoirs, salle d'écoute, réfectoires, cuisine, salle de jeux, salle de lecture, salles de cours, sanitaires et bureaux...

Au cas où l'objectif ne serait pas atteint, nous ne réhabiliterons que le rez-de-chaussée et poursuivrons la recherche de fonds pour le 1er étage.

Nous envisageons de dédier une des salles à tous nos donateurs et à toutes nos donatrices en y gravant leurs noms et de publier la liste de nos bienfaiteurs et bienfaitrices sur notre site internet www.ongcavoequiva.org

L'impact

Votre don permettra :

  1. d'assurer, pierre par pierre,  la réhabilitation concrète et immédiate du Centre de Transit Communautaire, dont les nouveaux plans architecturaux ont déjà été réalisés
  2. de garantir la sécurité matérielle et affective des enfants et jeunes filles vulnérables
  3. de contribuer à la réinsertion de ces enfants et jeunes filles dans leurs familles
  4. d'offrir aux pensionnaires, le temps de leur séjour au centre, un accès à l'alphabétisation et à la formation professionnelle
  5. de redonner le sourire à des enfants et à des jeunes filles blessées dans leur innocence en les réintégrant dans leur famille.

Pourquoi nous financer ?

Les centres d'hébergement temporaire ou de transit pour les enfants et les jeunes filles vulnérables sont presque inexistants à Abidjan (Côte d'Ivoire). Il est donc très important de soutenir notre structure afin de pérenniser nos actions et de sauver de nombreuses vies innocentes.

L'ONG Cavoequiva est bien implantée localement et a noué des partenariats avec des institutions internationales reconnues telles que Save the Children, ONUDC (Office des nations Unies contre la Drogue et la criminalité), Salevry Fund (Haut Commissariat des Nations Unies), la Fondation de Francen UNFPA (Fonds des nations Unies pour la Population...)

De  2011 à 2015 grâce à notre travail de terrain, nous avons recueilli 350 enfants et jeunes filles vulnérables et réunifié  255 d'entre elles.

Nos actions répondent à des besoins immédiats de mise en sécurité et de reconstruction des enfants et jeunes filles, dans une perspective de respect des droits humains et d'émancipation de la  femme.

Au début, nous accueillions les mineures vulnérables uniquement la journée. Mais, face aux dangers de viol et de mauvais traitements auxquels elles étaient exposées la nuit sur les sites de vulnérabilité, il nous est apparu urgent  de mettre en place un Centre de Transit Communautaire assurant une protection globale. 

Risques et défis

Les défis à relever, c'est d'arriver à réhabiliter et à équiper le Centre de Transit Communautaire de l'ONG Cavoequiva et d'en faire un centre de référence pour enfants et jeunes filles vulnérables en Côte d'Ivoire d'autant plus que le manque est criard. Nous pensons être en mesure de relever ces défis grâce à notre expérience dans le domaine et notre parfaite connaissance du terrain. Egalement, avec notre forte collaboration avec les structures étatiques et la communauté, l'ONG Cavoequiva est  bien intégrée dans le milieu associatif en Côte d'Ivoire.
Les risques ou obstacles auxquels nous pourrions être confrontés dans l'atteinte des objectifs ,c'est d'être confronté après la réhabilitation à une sollicitation très importante des structures référentes à laquelle nous ne pourrions pas faire face  vu que nous aurions un effectif bien déterminé à prendre en charge à la fois et un budget conséquent.
Pour palier ces difficultés, nous poursuivrons la mobilisation des fonds pour la prise en charge de ces enfants et optimiserons les recherches familiales  afin de réinsérer le maximum d'enfants en un temps record .  

D'autres façons d'aider

Certaines personnes ne peuvent pas contribuer mais cela ne veut pas dire qu'elles ne peuvent pas aider :

  • Demandez aux gens de passer le mot et de faire de la publicité autour de votre projet.
  • Rappelez-leur d'utiliser les outils de partage Indiegogo !

Toute personne peut aider d'une façon ou d'une autre. Il est possible d'aider en faisant la publicité du site à leurs amis, à leur entourage....

Et le tour est joué.

story:
The wolf is the only animal in the world that man has intentionally set out to eradicate, despite the fact that wolves are a key component of any ecosystem they inhabit. But while the reintroduction of wolves into Yellowstone National Park demonstrated that the presence of wolf populations are beneficial both environmentally and economically, reintroduction and wolf preservation efforts remain unpopular due to public misconceptions and prejudices about wolves. And now, wolves are yet again in danger of being eliminated from regions that desperately need them to remain healthy and beautiful.

We at Shadowland Foundation believe that the best way to safeguard wolves from human aggression is to educate people. By dispelling the various popular myths and superstitions about wolves and by allowing people to encounter and interact with wolves up close, we hope to help people realize that wolves are actually majestic and complex creatures that need to be nurtured and protected. Led by our founder Paul Pondella, Shadowland Foundation has hand raised a pack of wolves for visitors to meet and interact with, allowing us to offer an in-person wolf experience along with one-of-a-kind educational programs. At Shadowland, you can meet our wolves inside their enclosure, pet them, feed them, take pictures with them, and see for yourself what wolves are really like.


 But for Shadowland Foundation to continue its work protecting these wolves and educating the public, we need to grow: literally. The ranch where our wolves live needs to expand, both to provide larger and better educational facilities for more people, and to give our wolves better and safe accommodations. At the moment all of our tours with the wolves take place in an outdoor enclosure; but because wolves are nocturnal and we have to protect their sensitive eyesight, they can only do one tour a week.

Our plan is to convert a 4000 square foot barn already on our property into an education center where people can meet our wolves in an area free of UV light (allowing for more visits and therefore more visitors getting to meet the wolves).  Our annual operating budget is $138,000, which goes to care for the wolves. This leaves effectively no extra funding to expand, which is why we have come to you here on Indiegogo to help make our dream of a larger educational facility possible.


We want to make Shadowland Foundation a place that touches the lives of millions of people and helps show them the sensitive majesty of the wolf. We already have a Wolves & Warriors outreach program for veterans, but with your help Shadowland can also expand our education programs to schools, and provide field trips for inner city, underprivileged, and special needs children and adults.



$10 perk:
Cities Of Ether Stories ebook anthology by renowned author G. D. Falksen, and a $5 gift card to Detroit Leather.

$25 perk:
All previous perks above, a Spirit Of The Wolf charm, and one mini wolf print.



$45 perk:
All previous perks above, 6 mini wolf prints, and a Pack Leader leather bracelet.

$75 perk:
All previous perks above, the Shadowland Wolf tee shirt (S-XL) design by artist Evelyn Kriete, and 6 additional mini wolf prints (total of 12).

$150 perk:
All previous perks above, three exclusive wolf-inspired art prints by veteran Disney animator James Lopez, concept artist Nat Iwata, and fine artist Nikki Lyka (as the campaign goes on we will reveal the art pieces that will become these exclusive prints).



$200 perk:
All previous perks above, and an Alpha Wolf pendant.

$250 perk:
All previous perks above, and an amethyst Wolf Fang pendant.


$100 perk:
Chat with award-winning actor, screenwriter, and producer Mike C. Manning. You get to join in an exclusive chat with Mike where you can ask him anything. In addition, you will receive a Spirit Of The Wolf charm, 12 mini wolf prints, and a Pack Leader bracelet.

$1000 perk:
A weekend with the wolves. You and a friend will get to spend a weekend on our property. We will put you up and feed you dinner, and you will get to walk our land and spend time with our amazing wolf pack. You can schedule this weekend any time in the next two years (upon availability). Come on Friday, go home Sunday. We will love to have you. This perk is one per person maximum. In addition, you will receive a Spirit Of The Wolf charm, 12 mini wolf prints, a Pack Leader bracelet, and a Shadowland wolf tee shirt. If you have any questions about this perk before picking it up, feel free to message us.

$5000 perk:
Wolf Wedding. Have your wedding with us and the wolves. We have many great spots for an outdoor wedding, and if our barn is fully funded and ready you can also have a wedding there in our new indoor space. With this perk, you get to use our property for your special day and a photo op (up to two hours long) with our wolves. Yes, you can bring your own food, but please do not feed the animals! In addition, you will receive two Spirit Of The Wolf charms, 12 mini wolf prints, two Pack Leader bracelets, and two Shadowland wolf tee shirts. If you have any questions about this perk before picking it up, feel free to message us.



How important is it to try and educate the public about wolves? Extremely important. Although wolves are on the Endangered Species List, members of Congress, the Department of the Interior, and the US Fish & Wildlife Service have succumbed to pressure by special interest groups to implement policies allowing the circumvention of ESL protection. In 2011, when wolves first lost their protection, more than 2600 wolves out of a population of only 5000 were killed in the first two years. Hunting season in 2015 began on August 31, and brutal methods like trapping, gassing, and the use of dogs (which were outlawed decades ago) have been reapproved to target wolves. Hunting season has been extended to kill pregnant females and to allow the poisoning of pups before they can reach adulthood, which will devastate entire packs.

Shadowland Foundation strives to educate the citizens of wolf hunting states, along with the general population, so that they realize both that the eradication of wolves is cruel and unnecessary, and also that the loss of wolves is harmful to the states they formerly inhabited. In addition to ecological concerns, there is a financial matter at stake for these states. In 2010 in Yellowstone Park alone, almost a million and a half dollars was generated in eco-tourism, and almost half of this was attributed specifically to the presence of wolves. By educating people about wolves and the benefit they bring, we can make a difference.
story_txt:
The wolf is the only animal in the
world that man has intentionally set out to eradicate, despite the fact that wolves
are a key component of any ecosystem they inhabit. But while the reintroduction
of wolves into Yellowstone National Park demonstrated that the presence of wolf
populations are beneficial both environmentally and economically,
reintroduction and wolf preservation efforts remain unpopular due to public
misconceptions and prejudices about wolves. And now, wolves are yet again in
danger of being eliminated from regions that desperately need them to remain
healthy and beautiful.We at Shadowland Foundation believe
that the best way to safeguard wolves from human aggression is to educate
people. By dispelling the various popular myths and superstitions about wolves
and by allowing people to encounter and interact with wolves up close, we hope
to help people realize that wolves are actually majestic and complex creatures
that need to be nurtured and protected. Led by our founder Paul Pondella, Shadowland Foundation has hand raised a pack of wolves for visitors to meet and interact
with, allowing us to offer an in-person wolf experience along with
one-of-a-kind educational programs. At Shadowland, you can meet our wolves
inside their enclosure, pet them, feed them, take pictures with them, and see
for yourself what wolves are really like.


 But for Shadowland Foundation to
continue its work protecting these wolves and educating the public, we need to
grow: literally. The ranch where our wolves live needs to expand, both to
provide larger and better educational facilities for more people, and to give
our wolves better and safe accommodations. At the moment all of our tours with
the wolves take place in an outdoor enclosure; but because wolves are nocturnal
and we have to protect their sensitive eyesight, they can only do one tour a
week.Our plan is to convert a 4000
square foot barn already on our property into an education center where people
can meet our wolves in an area free of UV light (allowing for more visits and
therefore more visitors getting to meet the wolves).  Our annual operating budget is $138,000,
which goes to care for the wolves. This leaves effectively no extra funding to
expand, which is why we have come to you here on Indiegogo to help make our
dream of a larger educational facility possible.




We want to make Shadowland Foundation a place that touches the lives of millions of people and helps show
them the sensitive majesty of the wolf. We already have a Wolves & Warriors
outreach program for veterans, but with your help Shadowland can also expand
our education programs to schools, and provide field trips for inner city,
underprivileged, and special needs children and adults.


$10 perk:Cities Of Ether Stories ebook anthology by renowned author G. D. Falksen, and a $5 gift card to Detroit Leather.



$25 perk:All previous perks above, a Spirit Of The Wolf charm, and one mini wolf print.




$45 perk:All previous perks above, 6 mini wolf prints, and a Pack Leader leather bracelet.
$75 perk:All previous perks above, the Shadowland Wolf tee shirt (S-XL) design by artist Evelyn Kriete, and 6 additional mini wolf prints (total of 12).




$150 perk:All previous perks above, three exclusive 
wolf-inspired art prints by veteran Disney animator James Lopez, concept
 artist Nat Iwata, and fine artist Nikki Lyka (as the campaign goes on 
we will reveal the art pieces that will become these exclusive prints).




$200 perk:All previous perks above, and an Alpha Wolf pendant.





$250 perk:All previous perks above, and an amethyst Wolf Fang pendant.



$100 perk:Chat with award-winning actor, 
screenwriter, and producer Mike C. Manning. You get to join in an 
exclusive chat with Mike where you can ask him anything. In addition, 
you will receive a Spirit Of The Wolf charm, 12 mini wolf prints, and a 
Pack Leader bracelet.




$1000 perk:A weekend with the wolves. You and a friend will get to spend a weekend on our property. We will put you up 
and feed you dinner, and you will get to walk our land and spend 
time with our amazing wolf pack. You can schedule this weekend any time in the next two years (upon availability). Come on Friday, go home Sunday. We will love to have you. This perk is one per person maximum. In addition, you will receive a Spirit Of The Wolf charm, 12 mini wolf prints, a Pack Leader bracelet, and a Shadowland wolf tee shirt. If you have any questions about this perk 
before picking it up, feel free to message us.





$5000 perk: Wolf Wedding. Have your 
wedding with us and the wolves. We have many great spots for an outdoor 
wedding, and if our barn is fully funded and ready you can also have a 
wedding there in our new indoor space. With this perk, you get to use 
our property for your special day and a photo op (up to two hours long) 
with our wolves. Yes, you can bring your own food, but please do not 
feed the animals! In addition, you will receive two Spirit Of The Wolf 
charms, 12 mini wolf prints, two Pack Leader bracelets, and two 
Shadowland wolf tee shirts. If you have any questions about this perk 
before picking it up, feel free to message us.




How important is it to try and
educate the public about wolves? Extremely important. Although wolves are on
the Endangered Species List, members of Congress, the Department of the
Interior, and the US Fish & Wildlife Service have succumbed to pressure by
special interest groups to implement policies allowing the circumvention of ESL
protection. In 2011, when wolves first lost their protection, more than 2600
wolves out of a population of only 5000 were killed in the first two years.
Hunting season in 2015 began on August 31, and brutal methods like
trapping, gassing, and the use of dogs (which were outlawed decades ago) have
been reapproved to target wolves. Hunting season has been extended to kill
pregnant females and to allow the poisoning of pups before they can reach
adulthood, which will devastate entire packs.
Shadowland Foundation strives to
educate the citizens of wolf hunting states, along with the general population,
so that they realize both that the eradication of wolves is cruel and
unnecessary, and also that the loss of wolves is harmful to the states they
formerly inhabited. In addition to ecological concerns, there is a financial
matter at stake for these states. In 2010 in Yellowstone Park alone, almost a
million and a half dollars was generated in eco-tourism, and almost half of

story:
I am Daisy Arcilla Brett-Holt, a British-Filipino chairman of Worldwide Philippine Jury Initiative (WPJI).  Being a dual citizen, I thought it best to register WPJI as a non-government association both in UK and the Philippines.  My 30-year residence in the UK has shown me how life could be meaningful, productive and comfortable for me and my family.  The significant contrast between lives in my two countries made me search for the reason why.  This is what I found out _ the difference between British and Filipino attitudes to the legal system is due to the ingrained effect on the British of the Jury System.

So, what is or is not in the Filipino culture that makes the people who and what they are?  The simple answer is _ the absence of a Jury System!  I could not believe it at first; but as I analysed the situation, I became convinced that this time tested Jury System made the big difference between the Filipino and the English cultures, and as such the difference in these two kinds of people.

What the Filipinos have instead of the jury system is a Single-Judge System.  Everyone knows that even a well-meaning judge can be easily bribed or coerced.  But why have not the Filipinos changed this system?  The answer is :_ their leaders. The American colonizers imposed their constitution in 1902.  The jury system was omitted because they wanted to keep power out of the hands of ordinary Filipinos!  Since then, similarly, Filipino leaders wanted to monopolize the political and judicial powers to themselves.  They succeeded by keeping the people ignorant of their laws, rights and responsibilities. 

Only a jury system where the ordinary citizens have the final say whether to keep or sack their representatives in government can address this imbalance in power.  Winston Churchill once said, "Only as long as juries of ordinary citizens have the final say, the government remains the servant, not the master of the people".

I would like to share with my fellow Filipinos the blessings God has given me and the only way I can do it is by teaching the Jury System to the youth of the country who will benefit from this knowledge and  affect the "change" majority of the Filipino people so wanted.

On the 15th of July 2015, the Chairperson of Commission on Higher Education in the Philippines endorsed our National Information Tour on the Jury System for Filipinos.  In conjunction with the information tour, WPJI also has to gather 7 Million signatures out of 56 Million registered voters.  The signatures are pre-requisite to a National Referendum on the adoption of the jury system in the Philippine judiciary.

Your donations will help us tremendously as we tour the 234 Congressional Districts spread out in the 7100 islands of the Philippines.


What We Need & What You Get

Our Organization needs in total, $203,800.00.  Below is a breakdown of our budget for the 12 months of its operation.  

EXPENDITURES

Printing of:                         Petition Signature Sheets                   $        3,890                                                                                                            Leaflets                          156,000

USB (flash drive)                                                                                               1,482

Domestic flights (to 234 Districts)                                                          28,780

International Airfares (3 UK return flights at~ £708/flight)             3,400 

Office Supplies                                                                                                  3,000

Office Utilities (Electricity, water, Telephone, mobile, Dues)            2,267     

Salaries of 2 office clerks                                                                                2,815

Professional Fees of Accountant, Auditor, Lawyer                                2,200     

                                          BUDGET ESTIMATE FOR 12 months      $ 203,834

 The exchange rate at the time of computation is P45.00 per $1.00

We realize that this amount is too large for crowdfunding.  If we could get even just 10%, say $20,000 in 60 days, we will be very grateful.  With this money, we could have a lift-off and create an a sizeable impact among the grassroots in the country.

Even if we don't get this amount, our information tour will continue and keep applying for funding from other sources.  None of it will be wasted.

As a token of our gratitude, we will send postcards of Philippine scenic views for every $10.00 donation. 

The Impact

The Philippines is considered the sick man of Asia despite the fact that we have an intelligent and hard-working workforce known everywhere in the world.  Only our Overseas Filipino Workers' remittances  keep our country's economy afloat despite our President's drive to attract foreign investment.  Many businesses  are wary about investing in the Philippines due to rampant corruption.

The success of our campaign will enlighten peoples mostly in Asia where people are denied of their democratic rights.  If the Filipinos can do it, so can they.  The campaigners are pushing for this "change" silently and peacefully through a signature campaign on our petition for the enactment of a National Jury Law.  The fact, that an important official in the Office of the President endorsed our National Information Tour and Signature Campaign, could only mean that our campaign is gaining traction and we are on the right track!   

Risks & Challenges

Although our campaign is intended to be done quietly and peacefully, we cannot avoid the ire of people who stand to lose from the implementation of the jury law.  This being the case, we avoid naming names unless their names are already in the local and national news.  In discussions, we emphasize that we do not resort to character assassination.  We only point out what is wrong with our judicial system and show how the jury system can solve our problem of corruption that brought about poverty to millions of Filipinos.  
Many of our leaders and supporters belong to interfaith groups. Hence, we also espouse the spirit of reconciliation so as to unite the people towards a righteous and just Philippines  

Other Ways You Can Help

We call on our Indiegogo readers and donors to help us in whatever way they can. Tell you Facebook, Twitter, LinkedIn and other social media friends, Filipinos or not, to read about our campaign.  Advise them to use the Indiegogo share tools for an effective campaign.  The Worldwide Philippine Jury Initiative  members will be very grateful.  With your help, we can reach much more than we can.

story:
Meet Sorrun:* Cambodian national, hospitality worker, and friend. I first met Sorrun during a student internship in a Cambodian legal aid organization. He not only showed me the highlights of Phnom Penh and the surrounding provinces during my time there (stay tuned for an upcoming post on our travels) but also brought me into his circle of friends and family, who treated me as one of their own. In return and by sharing his story, I hope to raise enough funding for Sorrun to achieve his dream – a college degree.

SORRUN’S STORY

Sorrun hails from a family of farmers in the Cambodian countryside. He was a close relative and coworker of Chut Wutty, famed environmental activist who was fatally shot by the military police on April 26, 2012.** Sorrun worked with Mr. Wutty until shortly before his death and contributed to his efforts to expose illegal logging activities and land seizures facilitated by the Cambodian government.

Sorrun now works full-time in Phnom Penh to save enough to pursue a degree. If he achieves his goal, he will be the first of his family to attend a four-year university. Although the tuition for one year amounts to only about $450 USD, it is costly in a country where the minimum wage is just over $100 per month. The government presently provides very few scholarships for post-secondary education, and neither Sorrun nor his immediate family members earn enough income to qualify for a private loan.

OUR GOAL

The fall academic term in Cambodia begins in September 2015, and our goal is to raise enough for Sorrun to finance four years of study plus living expenses. Sorrun currently has enough savings to finance his first semester this fall, but he will need additional funding to maintain his enrollment status. Please feel free to give whatever you can spare—no amount is too small and all contributions will be much appreciated. If we overreach our goal, additional funds will be donated directly to a Cambodian account held for Sorrun and will not be diverted in any way. Thank you!!!

ANNUAL ESTIMATED EXPENSES

—Tuition and books → $450/year → $1575 for 7 semesters
—Housing →  ~$70/month →  ~$840/year
—Total budget for 1 year → $1,290

TOTAL GOAL → $5000

Yours truly,
Liz and Sorrun
#HelpFundSorrun
__________

*Sorrun’s name and personal details have been altered to protect his identity. An official investigation into the death of Mr. Wutty was never launched, and the lack of protection for freedom of speech means that Sorrun may not express his views without risking government intimidation or persecution. Although we prefer to use a pseudonym for purposes of this campaign, Sorrun’s legal name and identity have been independently verified and we are happy to answer any questions regarding Sorrun’s circumstances or the donation process more generally. Please feel free to contact me at lizbundy@umich.edu or +1 704-441-3077.

**Chut Wutty was killed while accompanying two journalists investigating illegal logging activities in a protected forest; his death was widely condemned as an unprovoked attack by military police. Mr. Wutty was posthumously recognized by Barack Obama and other political leaders for his activist role in environmentalism, and he is the subject of a documentary made in honor of his campaign against deforestation. For more information on Mr. Wutty’s life and work, please view the video and visit the links provided below.


http://www.phnompenhpost.com/post-weekend/three...
Three Years Since Shooting Death

http://www.theguardian.com/global-development/2...
Cambodia: Chut Wutty’s Legacy Creates an Opportunity for Land Justice

http://www.bbc.com/news/magazine-18032883
Chut Wutty’s Memory Spurs Anti-logging Campaign

story:
In less than 30 hours the concept of ACTING as a HEALING ART solidifies. 


Kripalu and New Theatre are linking up to do a staged reading about an actress who has just been cast in the role of HAMLET and yet she has a BLOCK. The question of to BE or not to BE hits on many levels and as we follow the actress through her journey. We hope to express   how understanding ones self is of utmost importance when choosing your roles both on and off stage.

Much love

S


South Florida's Hit Play Women Playing Hamlet is headed to Kripalu in the Berkshires!

A new twist on Hamlet will heat up the Berkshires this summer at a first-of-its-kind event uniting South Florida’s New Theatre, the leader in developing new voices for the stage along with Susie K. Taylor, to Kripalu Center for Yoga & Health, one of the country’s most famous Yoga institutes. Set for August 12, 2015, at 7:30 pm, the educational and entertaining evening will feature a staged reading and talk back of William Missouri Downs’ fun loving and profound comedy Women Playing Hamlet, which had its National New Play Network’s Rolling Premiere at New Theatre to rave reviews.
Christine Dolen of The Miami Herald called Women Playing Hamlet “engaging” and “graceful” and 

Bill Hirschman of FloridaTheatreOnStage noted it as “a very funny play...digs deeply into that alchemical process when an actor draws on their own life experience to create a creature nearly impossible to discern as a character in a play on a stage.”

Linking South Florida’s New Theatre and Susie K. Taylor with the Berkshire’s Kripalu is sure to BE an exciting and unforgettable evening!

REUNITING the Brilliant  director Ricky J. Martinez with the stellar ALL FEMALE cast in the Berkshires? 
To be or not to be ......That is  the question?


What We Need & What You Get

O! for a horse with wings!  ~William Shakespeare, Cymbeline

We need...

to raise the final funds to cover artists' costs such as flight, lodging, transportation, meals etc...totaling  $6000 

You GET

Good Karma

Your FULLY TAX-DEDUCTIBLE donation will literally help us FLY!

No contribution is too large or too small, everything counts.  


The Impact

The production on Aug 12th will be an unplugged version of the original full production with a  focus more on the acting  and the story! 

This evening will be a marriage of MANY concepts.

*ACTING as a healing art

*TAKING South Florida to the Berkshires!

*TAKING New Theatre to Kripalu!

*BRINGING Shakespeare to Women

* Hamlet to the Creative 

The impact is endless!


To donate or no to donate...There is no question! 

This is sure to be the BEgining of a beautiful relationship! 




Risks & Challenges

It is not in the stars to hold our destiny but in ourselves.

William Shakespeare


Having  Kripalu invite us up to perform Women Playing Hamlet is a huge honor and a testament to where the healing arts are moving to.


The challenges and the Risks are ingrained in the life of an artist! 

Supporting new relationships like this is important as it helps to strengthen both communities in their mission to heal!

Please join me and help get New Theatre's production of Women Playing Hamlet EXPORTED to the Berkshires and in doing so shine a light on MIAMI talents and new voices in the theatre!


Other Ways You Can Help

Share this post on your Facebook and other social media links.

Happen to be in the BERKS on Aug 12th BUT YOUR TICKETS for dinner and a play reading!

CALL and reserve you ticket ASAP

For further details you can visit their site http://kripalu.org

Tickets are available for sale.  (866.200.5203) and reference the event code: WPHEE-151.  The ticket is for dinner and a play for $30. 

Spread the word and share the link!
story_txt:
In less than 30 hours the concept of ACTING as a HEALING ART solidifies. 

Kripalu and New Theatre are linking up to do a staged reading about an actress who has just been cast in the role of HAMLET and yet she has a BLOCK. The question of to BE or not to BE hits on many levels and as we follow the actress through her journey. We hope to express   how understanding ones self is of utmost importance when choosing your roles both on and off stage.
Much love
S

South Florida's Hit Play Women Playing Hamlet is headed to Kripalu in the Berkshires!

A new twist on Hamlet will heat up the Berkshires this summer at a first-of-its-kind event
uniting South Florida’s New Theatre, the leader in developing new voices for the stage along
with Susie K. Taylor, to Kripalu Center for Yoga & Health, one of the country’s most famous
Yoga institutes. Set for August 12, 2015, at 7:30 pm, the educational and entertaining evening
will feature a staged reading and talk back of William Missouri Downs’ fun loving and profound
comedy Women Playing Hamlet, which had its National New Play Network’s Rolling Premiere
at New Theatre to rave reviews.

Christine Dolen of The Miami Herald called Women Playing Hamlet “engaging” and “graceful”
and 


Bill Hirschman of FloridaTheatreOnStage noted it as “a very funny play...digs deeply into
that alchemical process when an actor draws on their own life experience to create a creature
nearly impossible to discern as a character in a play on a stage.”

Linking South Florida’s New Theatre and Susie K. Taylor with the Berkshire’s Kripalu is sure to BE an exciting and unforgettable evening!




REUNITING the Brilliant  director Ricky J. Martinez with the stellar ALL FEMALE cast in the Berkshires? 
To be or not to be ......That is  the question?
    What We Need & What You Get 
O! for a horse with wings!  ~William Shakespeare, Cymbeline
We need...
to raise the final funds to cover artists' costs such as flight, lodging, transportation, meals etc...totaling  $6000 
You GET
Good Karma
Your FULLY TAX-DEDUCTIBLE donation will literally help us FLY!
No contribution is too large or too small,
everything counts.  


The Impact

The production on Aug 12th will be an unplugged
version of the original full production with a  focus more on the acting  and the story! 
This evening will be a marriage of MANY concepts.
*ACTING as a healing art
*TAKING South Florida to the Berkshires!
*TAKING New Theatre to Kripalu!
*BRINGING Shakespeare to Women
* Hamlet to the Creative 
The impact is endless!

To donate or no to donate...There is no question! 
This is sure to be the BEgining of a beautiful relationship! 




    Risks & Challenges 
It is not in the stars to hold our destiny but in ourselves.
William Shakespeare

Having  Kripalu invite us up to perform Women Playing Hamlet is a huge honor and a testament to where the healing arts are moving to.

The challenges and the Risks are ingrained in the life of an artist! 
Supporting new relationships like this is important as it helps to strengthen both communities in their mission to heal!
Please join me and help get New Theatre's production of Women Playing Hamlet EXPORTED to the Berkshires and in doing so shine a light on MIAMI talents and new voices in the theatre!
