story:
on the web  

TRADUÇÃO CAMPANHA

Dear Reader,

If you were born and raised in a free and developed country, you only start to understand how lucky you are, once you travel to a country without those characteristics. Even simple necessities like electricity, clean water, sewage are non-existant, or only available to the upper class.

I married my Brazilian wife in 1998 and we lived in Amsterdam. During the family visits to Brazil, I understood why Brazil is still called a third-world country. 

Despite housing some of the richest people in the world and having one of the worlds highest tax incomes, in many places development of public infrastructure is stuck in the 18th century. Mainly due to the outrageous government corruption.

Brazil has major potential, but this potential stays underdeveloped, because of lack of access to proper education. If only the people could be connected to the internet at very low cost or even free, the internet could fill up the gap in education.

In 2010 I started up our Dutch-Brazilian company, with as its sole purpose to connect the unconnected in Brazil to the internet. In the following years we acquired the license to offer our connection in the whole Brazilian territory, established a small datacenter, created a small pilot project, participated in government tenders and prepared over 20 projects in three states. 

All this we have achieved with the help of 74 backers who along the years together put up $250.000.


Despite the very positive reactions of civil servants at the Brazilian ministry of telecommunications, and our best price at the government tenders, we still did not win any tender. Due to our refusal to participate in corruption. 



Project Caputera

Project Caputera is one where we can place our Integrated Radio Masts on condominio grounds, without interference of corrupt government officials. 

The project is divided into 6 phases, and we are now raising the money to execute the first three. We estimate that we can connect 250 houses until June 2015, and a thousand more until December 2015. 

http://www.adoptawifizoneinbrazil.net.br

We will be charging a connection fee of $35 per month, for those who can afford it, and we will create free access points for those who cannot. After all, if you have no drinking water, internet is not going to be your first concern.



Funding

Even with our highly efficient and economic Integrated Radio Mast and our team of volunteers we still do need to invest more money before we get to the breakeven point. 

We have chosen the flexible funding principle, because even if we are unable to raise the whole amount, with smaller amounts we get there too. It will just take longer.

We are not a non-profit company. We want to make a fair profit (35%) so we can grow gradually, creating jobs, innovation and education. In my view the most social thing to do is create equal opportunities, and invest in them. 

And there is a lot still to be done. Thirty-eight million households in Brazil are not connected to the internet yet. 

Who are we looking for?

If you are reading this and you are in India, you would have your own non-developed internet to think about first. And if you are in Greece, you have other worries altogether. 

I am appealing to the reader who thinks beyond governments, countries and cultures. A reader who looks upon this planet as an astronaut does: a beautiful blue fragile sphere hanging out in total darkness. 


We cannot afford to wait for governments trying to resolve trade barriers. We cannot wait  for countries to form free trade zones. We cannot wait for cultural differences to be merged into one idyllic super culture. 

The closest and affordable alternative to being an astronaut is being an internaut. Let’s connect those who are unconnected.

Best regards,

Richard Kloostra - Founder & Director Riklsat Enterprises


What we do with your funds

As said above we have chosen the flexible funding principle. The amount that will comfortably realize the first three phases of project Caputera is roughly $200 K. We have set our goal at $300 K though, to prepare for (probable) taxes on the raised amount, for (probable) delays when importing equipment, for (probable) legal and accounting costs,  and to comfortably deliver the perks while installing the project.

Below you’ll find a pie chart explaining expected spending for the Caputera project.

If we raise lower amounts we will go slower, if we raise more will we go faster. Aside from the perks we will keep you posted about the progress by giving you a user account on our discussion platform www.ourcompanytogether.com 

The coming months we will be introducing our other projects on indiegogo, raising the bar every time. 

What do we do with profit?

As mentioned above, we are not a non-profit company. We are just not as attractive for traditional investors as the average fortune 500 company, because of our social way of looking at profit. 

We believe that creating well paid jobs is profit. We believe that our customers, employees and suppliers are our investors too. We believe all of these stakeholders should have real influence on company policy. 

To get a better idea about our base rules on dividend and employee participation take a look at these links:

On profits, dividend and general economics, billionaire mr. Nick Hanauer: http://www.ted.com/talks/nick_hanauer_beware_fe...

On employee participation award winning Brazilian entrepreneur mr. Ricardo Semler: https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=USC1RE8jE50 & http://www.npo.nl/tegenlicht/04-02-2013/VPWON_1... 

Your Perks

If you are still here it means we are now on the same page. You now understand why it is so hard for us to get funded. 

We have some perks to attend basic needs:

    


Crowdfunding by law does not allow us to offer you shares or other future financial gains, so we have invented some small amount perks that will give you the feeling that you are really helping out. Your support will not be forgotten. 


For major investors or businesses we have included perks based on our experience on setting up a business in Brasil.

And for the adventurous type, we offer a type of internship in Brazil.

Your Impact

If you have watched the Semler and Hanauer talks, there is not much to add about the impact. We will be creating equal opportunities and continue to invest in them. The more people join this way of life, the less inequity will exist. 

I would like to leave you with the artist impression that our backer Lisa Cruysberg made about the impact, and about our continuous funding efforts.



Risks & Challenges

Our Caputera project has a timetable for realization until December 2015. The main factor slowing us down is import delay. We have two initiatives going to improve on that. 

One is obtaining an unrestricted import license, called Radar/Siscomex. We started the application for it in 2011, when we imported our pilot project Sitio Santa Rosa. As mentioned before we do not condone participating in corruption, therefore obtaining these licenses take much longer than they should.

The other one, which is local fabrication, removes the import problem altogether. On local fabrication we are negotiating with three parties, two techno parks and a university. 

Your Contribution

If you decide to contribute, but you cannot afford large amounts, know that that’s the idea of crowdfunding. Many times $11 gets the job done too. We have gotten this far with 74 people investing on average $75 a month. Imagine where we will get with 3.000 people doing that.

And if you are not in the position to contribute financially, but you do support the general idea, please spread the word around. Besides your own networks LinkedIn, facebook, googleplus, the Indiegogo platform provides tools to inform others about our project.

We thank you for taking the time to read, and hope to welcome you soon as one of our backers.

story:
We are The Global Initiative for the Youth of Haiti – and our primary goal is to provide Haitian students with access to further education.

We believe that in order for Haiti to move forward and compete on a global scale we must educate the next generation of Haitian Youth

We are committed to facilitating university programs both in Haiti and overseas, providing the youth of Haiti with further education, a global perspective and life skills.

Our vision is to provide further education to the local Haitian high school students, enabling Haiti to raise a generation of professionals, innovators and leaders.

Education is the key to unlock the golden door of freedom.

- George Washington Carver -

How The Program Works

The Global Initiative for the Youth of Haiti will provide benefits for recent high school graduates of Haiti, who would otherwise be unable to further their education due to the lack of finances, resource and family support. There is also limited capacity within existing Haitian colleges and universities, making the competition extremely high and outcomes low.

Our program promotes Haitians giving back to Haitians. 

A pre-requisite of the program will be an agreed amount of time spent working in Haiti, following graduation. This will enable the students to give back to their local communities and benefit the growth and progression of Haiti.

We want to make a student's dream of getting a full education a reality.

At the Global Initiative for the Youth of Haiti we promote education because it is every student’s right to gain knowledge, to think, to create and to have equal in the world.

An investment in knowledge pays the best interest.

- Benjamin Franklin -

How The Global Initiative for the Youth of Haiti works

The Global Initiative for the Youth of Haiti is a non-profit and we rely on the kindness, donations and contributions of people just like you.

With your support we can change thousand’s of lives and the fate of a nation.

We know how important it is for every nation to stand on its own and be an active contributor to the world. This is the dream of millions of Haitians, and through our program we will provide further education for thousands of young students who can make this a reality for Haiti.

 

With your support and contributions we will deliver our programmes of support, education and resource to the Youth of Haiti.

The direction in which education starts a man will determine his future in life.

- Plato -

 




WHY WE ARE CROWDFUNDING

Our hope is that through this crowdfunding campaign we will impact the lives of many Haitian youth, providing hope and encouragement for thousands.

By crowdfunding we can touch the lives of many in a positive way, and we hope to connect with fellow students, educators and those with compassion for others through this campaign.

We know that by spreading our message to all of you who believe in the power of education we can fund this program and provide a sustainable further education program for many generations to come.

So please join us and do whatever you can to support our campaign. Every thing you can do to help us is greatly appreciated. Contributions, donations, sharing the message on social media, it all helps and with your help we will change the future of a nation.

Encouragement of higher education for our youth is critical to the success of our collective future.

- Charles B Rangel -

Why You Should Support the Global Initiative for the Youth of Haiti

We have one goal!

Our goal is to make every students dream of getting an education a reality. You will hear about the many relief programs providing food and shelter and other resources for the people of Haiti all the time. These are necessary support system, and are definitely needed. However we believe in helping the nation of Haiti to truly get back on their feet and become a self-sufficient nation of the future. 

As the saying goes, “if you give a man a fish he will eat for a day – if you teach a man to fish he will eat for a lifetime.”

Many of us have changed our own lives through a good education, strong support system and the necessary resource to make our futures secure and our dreams a reality.

Our program is unique in that we are focussed on helping the nation of Haiti take the next step in its development, by educating those who are capable of changing the future of the entire nation.

So help us to educate the future leaders, doctors, teachers, lawyers, creators, inventors and great thinkers of Haiti.

HOW YOU CAN HELP

Our youth deserve the opportunity to complete their high school and college education. Their future children deserve the opportunity to grow up in financially and emotionally stable homes. Every community benefits from healthy, productive, well-prepared young people.

- Jane Fonda -

  • Please share our campaign on social media, with friends, family and loved ones.

  • Tell everyone you know about this campaign and how easy it is to make a difference to an entire nation.

  • Support us with donations of any amount. We recognise you and appreciate you for every single dollar that you contribute.

  • Educate others around you to the difference that education can make to lives and eventually a nation of people.

We thank you for your generosity and support and the difference you are helping us to make.

THE GOAL

We want to raise $300,000

by raising this amount we will be able to send 150 students to university in Haiti for 1 year

This is only the beginning of our programme.

We also have some stretch goals in mind that we would love to achieve…

$25,000 – we can send 10 students to university in Haiti for 1 year

$50,000 – we can bring 20 students to university in Haiti for 1 year

$100,000 – we can bring 50 students to university in Haiti for 1 year

With the funds raised we can provide education, accommodation, travel and financial support for these students.

When we achieve our stretch goals we can begin to really make an impact of the lives of students who deserve an education

Thank you so much for reading our campaign – we look forward to your support and I’m sure you agree with our visionaries, celebrities and legends that the key to every future is education.

When you encourage others, you in the process are encouraged because you're making a commitment and difference in that person's life. Encouragement really does make a difference.

- Zig Ziglar -

provide benefits for recent high school graduates of Haiti, who would otherwise
be unable to further their education due to the lack of finances, resource and
family support. There is also limited capacity within existing Haitian colleges
and universities, making the competition extremely high and outcomes low. 
Our
program promotes Haitians giving back to Haitians. 
A pre-requisite of the program will be an
agreed amount of time spent working in Haiti, following graduation. This will
enable the students to give back to their local communities and benefit the
growth and progression of Haiti.
We want to make a student's dream of getting a
full education a reality.
At the Global Initiative for the Youth of Haiti
we promote education because it is every student’s right to gain knowledge, to
think, to create and to have equal in the world. 



An investment in knowledge pays the best interest.
-
Benjamin Franklin - 









How The Global Initiative for the
Youth of Haiti works



The Global Initiative
for the Youth of Haiti is a non-profit and we rely on the kindness, donations
and contributions of people just like you. 
With your support we
can change thousand’s of lives and the fate of a nation. 

We know how important
it is for every nation to stand on its own and be an active contributor to the
world. This is the dream of millions of Haitians, and through our program we
will provide further education for thousands of young students who can make
this a reality for Haiti. 
  





With your support and
contributions we will deliver our programmes of support, education and resource
to the Youth of Haiti. 












The
direction in which education starts a man will determine his future in life.


-
Plato - 




 


WHY WE ARE
CROWDFUNDING



Our hope is that
through this crowdfunding campaign we will impact the lives of many Haitian
youth, providing hope and encouragement for thousands.

By crowdfunding we
can touch the lives of many in a positive way, and we hope to connect with
fellow students, educators and those with compassion for others through this
campaign. 
We know that by
spreading our message to all of you who believe in the power of education we
can fund this program and provide a sustainable further education program for
many generations to come. 

So please join us and
do whatever you can to support our campaign. Every thing you can do to help us
is greatly appreciated. Contributions, donations, sharing the message on social
media, it all helps and with your help we will change the future of a nation.



Encouragement
of higher education for our youth is critical to the success of our collective
future.
-
Charles B Rangel - 








Why You Should Support the Global
Initiative for the Youth of Haiti


We have one goal! 
Our goal is to make
every students dream of getting an education a reality. You will hear about the
many relief programs providing food and shelter and other resources for the
people of Haiti all the time. These are necessary support system, and are
definitely needed. However we believe in helping the nation of Haiti to truly
get back on their feet and become a self-sufficient nation of the future.  

As the saying goes, “if
you give a man a fish he will eat for a day – if you teach a man to fish he will
eat for a lifetime.”

Many of us have
changed our own lives through a good education, strong support system and the
necessary resource to make our futures secure and our dreams a reality. 
Our program is unique
in that we are focussed on helping the nation of Haiti take the next step in its
development, by educating those who are capable of changing the future of the
entire nation. 



So help us to educate the future leaders,
doctors, teachers, lawyers, creators, inventors and great thinkers of Haiti.












HOW YOU CAN HELP




Our
youth deserve the opportunity to complete their high school and college
education. Their future children deserve the opportunity to grow up in
financially and emotionally stable homes. Every community benefits from
healthy, productive, well-prepared young people.
-
Jane Fonda - 




Please share our campaign on social media, with
friends, family and loved ones. 



Tell everyone you know about this campaign and
how easy it is to make a difference to an entire nation.



Support us with donations of any amount. We
recognise you and appreciate you for every single dollar that you contribute.


Educate others around you to the difference that
education can make to lives and eventually a nation of people.




We
thank you for your generosity and support and the difference you are helping us
to make.




THE GOAL


We want to raise $300,000


by raising this amount we will be able to send
150 students to university in Haiti for 1 year 
This is only the
beginning of our programme. 
We also have some
stretch goals in mind that we would love to achieve…
$25,000 – we can send
10 students to university in Haiti for 1 year
$50,000 – we can bring
20 students to university in Haiti for 1 year
$100,000 – we can
bring 50 students to university in Haiti for 1 year
With the funds raised
we can provide education, accommodation, travel and financial support for these
students. 
When we achieve our stretch goals we
can begin to really make an impact of the lives of students who deserve an
education
Thank you so much for reading our
campaign – we look forward to your support and I’m sure you agree with our visionaries,
celebrities and legends that the key to every future is education.



When
you encourage others, you in the process are encouraged because you're making a
commitment and difference in that person's life. Encouragement really does make
a difference.
-
Zig Ziglar -

story:
Who We Are

Jason Sage is a founding member of Telesma, a touring multimedia arts and music group which formed in 2002. With over 20 years of experience in arts organizations and event production, he has collaborated and worked with diverse groups and individuals including: The Baltimore Symphony, Center Stage, Alex Grey (of the Chapel of Sacred Mirrors), Robert Hieronimus, The New Orleans Voodoo Museum, BellyPalooza, The Creative Alliance, A.V.A.M. and The Visionary Solstice Gathering.

Photo by Philip Edward Laubner

 

Molly Szpara is a librarian, writer, and RYT 200 certified yoga instructor with a B.A. from Towson University. Her experience is in writing, wellness, meditation, yoga, childcare, event planning and community building. Molly has worked at Towson University and Johns Hopkins University in Housing and Residence Life as well as for The Center for Talented Youth. She has been published in "Nano Bio" Magazine,  "The Calvert Quarterly," "The Towerlight," and completed an Honors Thesis in Poetry. Molly has worked and volunteered in yoga studios and with KarmaFest, teaching yoga and facilitating events and retreats since 2009.

Photo by Philip Edward Laubner

 

Welcome to our FAMily...


Firehouse Arts & Music, or F.A.M., is a multi-disciplinary art and learning center opening in Baltimore, MD, in September 2016. F.A.M. is located in the Bromo Arts District.  Contributors to this campaign will help us provide a unique space in Baltimore City for learning, fun, and artistic expression! In the midst of tension and fear we’re experiencing worldwide and as a city, coming together to find common ground is more important than ever. Creating together creates community, and we want to be a place for that to thrive.

Daveed Korup is an arts-integration specialist who will be teaching percussion classes for Kids (KIDS DRUM) and adults (Tao Te Drum Curriculum). More about Daveed Korup

 

Our Mission

To provide fun, affordable classes, workshops and events taught by professional artists and instructors of all mediums and disciplines in the Baltimore Area. F.A.M.'s classes target the whole person: body, mind, spirit. By offering yoga and meditation classes to compliment classes in the arts and music, we hope to help our community express creatively while practicing self-care and expansion of consciousness. Many artists in our community are already practitioners of some kind of meditation, and find that this supports their emotional balance and creative process. FAM would like to foster both!

F.A.M. is both a community of artists and instructors whose philosophy is teamwork and interdependence (encourage one another, help each other out, pay it forward!) and a safe, urban space for being creative, whatever the art or practice may be.  We are not a yoga studio, art studio, band practice space, healing space, art gallery, music venue or art studio- strictly-- as a flex space, we’re all of the above!

 

Our Monetary Goals:

 

Initial Goal: $25,000 - Reaching this goal will help with startup costs like: furnishings, software and technology, modular stages, insurance, rent, and utilities. With this help we can hit the ground running with weekly yoga/dance and other community-priced classes and book workshops and special events immediately.

Stretch Goal 1: $30,000 will help with start up costs even more! We can acquire better music gear, art supplies and yoga equipment.  With this level of help we can offer more frequent community-priced (sliding scale, donation, or $10 or under) classes and activities every week right from the beginning.

Stretch Goal 2: $35,000 Reaching this goal will help with all of the above, plus enabling us to offer consistent community priced classes, as well as scholarships for workshops and classes.

Stretch Goal 3: $50,000 Reaching this goal will help FAM take care of everything listed above, deck the space out with technology and gear for all kinds of art events, and begin to offer free after school yoga and art classes to local students aged 12-18.

Stretch Goal 4: $60,000 Will help with ALL of the above, and will kickstart projects for the building like sprinklers and an elevator or stair lift to increase safety and capacity.  Other projects envisioned include acquiring a FAMily urban farm from which we can host urban homesteading and cooking classes.

 

F.A.M. will offer a weekly schedule of drop-in classes in:

  • Kundalini, Vinyasa, & Hatha Yoga 
  • Ballet, modern, hip-hop, and fusion dance classes for kids and adults
  • Select Martial Arts like Jiu Jitsu, Tai Chi Standing Meditation, and Kung Fu
  • Mindfulness Meditation
  • Percussion classes for Kids and Adults
Aliyah Johnson is both a yoga and dance instructor. She will be teaching classes in both movement arts at Firehouse Arts and Music. More about Aliyah and her professional instruction.
 
Lindsey Golden is a professional dance, yoga, and movement arts instructor and founder of the Golden Dance Experiement. 

 
Daniel Rahayel created and is leading the Daily Kundalini Sadhana program at Firehouse Arts & Music. Daniel is a certified hatha and Kundalini yoga instructor. 
 

Weekly and Monthly Community Events:

  • Baltimore Drum Church
  • Themed Lectures/Talks like the Psychedelic Seminars
  • Community-priced Acupuncture, Reiki, and Massage Healing Days
  • Potlucks/Community Meal
  • Open Mics & Open Music Jam/Improv Nights
  • Kirtan and Devotional Chanting/ Singing

 

Jasaga David Sawyer is a poet, writer, artist and activist working with Firehouse Arts & Music.
 
 

F.A.M. will be available to Rent For:

  • Your Creative Art, Music, or Healing Arts/Yoga-Centered Event, Class, or Workshop
  • Band Practice Space
  • Shooting Photography and/or Video in a studio setting
  • Weddings
  • Other private events

 

What We've Done So Far:

 

“My friends Jason and Molly put together multimedia shows in Baltimore. In addition to music, a light and video show, live painting, dance and performance, they also featured speakers who spoke of art and social topics, a comedian, a tarot card reader, a massage station and even some market stalls.” -Philip Edward Laubner after Spark the Firehouse 6

 

Hosted and organized 7 successful art/mixed-media events at the Windup Space: 

Ayla Roda and Michelle Wozniak were featured artists at multiple FAM events at the Windup Space

  • Local visual artists vended their work, many for the first time

Esther Polak and Amy Eskins vend art and crochet'd items at a FAM event at the Windup Space

  • Collaborations between musicians of different genres (spanning hip-hop, psychedelic, soul, funk, musical theatre, opera, rap, EDM, and gypsy-jazz) occurred at each event

Ian Hesford of Telesma and Shodekeh Taifero jam at a FAM event

 

Conor Brendan of the Wild Hunt and Kim Gravatt of Fractal Cat and Slow Lights jam at a FAM event

The Memorial Players of Memorial Episcopal Church perform a teaser from the musical, Ragtime at a FAM event.

 

  • Connections were made across art mediums and social scenes, resulting in further professional collaborations

Hillary Moon of the Golden Dance Experiment improvs with Dominic Fragman, multi-instrumentalist

 

  • A "FAM" Collaborative Art piece was created during the course of the previous events

Scott Frias is a Meta-Painter/ Maker of collaborative art pieces and leader of musical improv jams.

Maryamma Eswaran Para Tan paints on the collaborative FAM mural

Sophie Carey contributes to the collaborative FAM mural by Scott Frias

 

Co-Produced Sounds of Spirit: Music for the Inner Journey Sound Healing Concert at Earth Pulse Yoga, April 2016

Sounds of Spirit: Music for the Inner Journey previewing their concert at FAM's January Windup Space event.

 

Co-Produced the first and second Baltimore Drum Church Services in April and May 2016:

The March 2016 Baltimore Drum Church at Baltimore Yoga Village, Hampden

 

Baltimore Drum Church's latest Meditative Groove. More here.

 

Perks

FAM has been lucky to have worked all year with a talented community of Baltimore artists, instructors and musicians. If you donate to this campaign, you can receive their work as a preview of what's to come when the space opens, Firehouse Arts & Music Merchandise and passes to select classes and workshops upon opening.

  • Firehouse Arts & Music Official Button

  • FAMily Year Membership & Button

  • Firehouse Arts & Music Mug

  • Firehouse Arts & Music T-Shirt

  • Firehouse Arts & Music Tank Top

  • All FAMily items to be printed with our logo, designed by grahic artist, Dani Baer: 

  • Telesma CD

  • Fractal Cat CD

 

  • Whirlwinds CD & DVD package: 

      • "Whirlwinds- the Tao te drum sessions is a melding of two unique video shoots: the first at the Columbia Music Festival Association Studio in late 2001 (that's Columbia South Carolina); and the second was in October 2005 in an old church, turned recording studio in Pittsburg PA. A rhythmical odyssey within the revolving sphere of improvisational percussive conversation. Counting rhythms for many folks is kind of like someone taking their fingernails and scratching a chalkboard. It can grate on you when you don't have the confidence. The confidence comes from the doing... The magic of fusing dance with music opens the door to limitless possibilities in communicating the wonder of life's little mysteries. A philosophy and approach to hand drumming, the Tao Te Drum guided my work for over twenty years. You are invited to share in my adventure. Instructional DVD. Alechem Shalom ~Daveed Korup"

 

  • Hookman Redemption, a feature-length film by Nick Szpara

 

  • Art by Will Shanklin

 

  • Art by Aminah Shourbaji

 

  • Art by Dani Baer

 

  • Art by Tziona Nessaiver

 

  • Art by Summer Blake

 

  • Art by Jenny Rodziewicz

 

  • Art by Denise Williams

 

  • Art by Ayla Roda

 

  • Personalized Star/Birth Chart by Josef Kardell

 

  • The FAMily Package- 4 prints, 2 CDs, and a professional yoga mat 

 

  • One Week of Daily Kundalini Sadhana Yoga Classes upon opening

 

  • Pass to a Community Workshop or 2 Community Drop- In Classes upon opening

  • Half or Full Day Rental of our Historic Firehouse Space

More images to follow when renovation has progressed

 

 

We appreciate any support for this venture!

story: This summer from June to July, I will be residing in Germany while studying abroad. I will be attending a month long class in Freibrug, Germany that will open up a multitude of opportunities for me at not only the University of Tennessee, but also throughout my professional life. The trip is being funded through scholarships, savings, and even loans if necessary. Sadly however, the cost of the trip will most likely exceed the scholarships and savings I have this far. That is why I have started this fundraiser. I am hoping to raise funds to be able to help offset the out of pocket costs such as my flight, meals, and travel within Europe. While getting to study abroad by itself will be the experience of a life time, I also hope to be able to visit and travel within Europe during the little free time I have. While the majority of my time will be in Germany, my trip could include visits to France, Switzerland, Italy, and the Netherlands. Freibrug is such a central location that I am just hours away by train from many major cities! So please donate and help me to make this the experience of a lifetime as I study abroad in Freiburg, Germany!

story:
I've been teaching college writing and literature for five years now. I hold an MA in English, an MFA in Creative Writing, and have presented and spoken on the function of superheroes as our cultural mythology at academic conferences and school programs and ceremonies. This campaign will enable me to translate my most popular class, Constructing American Heroes, into an online course optimized for adult schedules. Instead of reading works of literature, we'll be watching selections from Marvel's Cinematic Universe. If you have time to watch one movie a week, you have time to take the course! Each contributor will be signed up for the eight week course, enabling me to focus on the quality of the experience over the summer months.

$500 is the minimum Indiegogo will allow for campaigns. But I'll move forward with the course with however many willing students sign up. For the $20 registration fee, you'll learn to recognize seven different archetypes in film and literature. You'll find out how each appeals to and serves our culture, and you'll have the chance to make a personal connection with one of the characters through a personal essay (optional) to be commented on by myself and the class.

This course has helped students locate our own cultural mythology within the history of Western Civilization. It has helped them read these stories as cultural indicators of societal fears and values. Students have gained a greater understanding of themselves and their mythological heritage.


You can help by signing up for the course and by sharing it with friends and family. Post it to Facebook, Twitter, and elsewhere. Help me spread the news about this unique opportunity to delve deeper into the meanings of the cultural phenomenon we call superheroes.

story:
What is SpyBox?

 

I'm Johnny Woods Jr., and I'm a father, teacher, student and an extreme boxing fan. Like me, many fans have memories tied to great fights, and fighters. The recent rise of mixed martial arts, and the ever-growing suspicion of greed and corruption in boxing have caused many fans to develop a love/hate relationship with the sport. They love the sport, but hate pay-per-views and politics. SpyBox was born out of fan frustration; the frustration over politics, promoters, and a pay-per-view system that far too often results in fans, and fighters, never seeing the match-ups they want, and/or when they want them. The SpyBox vision lies in changing where, how and when fans view fights so that we will be able to see great fights more regularly for free, and not at the whims of pay-per-view or premium cable channels.

 

What We Need

 

This campaign will help us accomplish five things:

1) Build a user friendly website dedicated to live streaming.

2) Purchase HD Cameras and equipment necessary for live streaming events.

3) Secure rights to classic fight footage for the online archive.

4) Initial staffing of our production team. 

5) Travel expenses for the production team covering live events.

Check out our perks and choose the one(s), that make you smile and feel free to share our campaign by clicking on the Facebook and Twitter links. 

 

Our Impact

 

IMAGINE

NO pay per view fights

and

seeing the fights you want when fighters are in their prime.

For years fighters and the sport of boxing have fought a reputation for corruption and greed. Right now an opportunity exists to flip the pay per view structure, taking power away from cable providers, promoters, and pay per view distributors. The development of online live streaming technology puts the fans and fighters back in control of fights once more.  

 

The Team

 

Johnny Woods Jr. - Mr. Woods is the brains behind SpyBox, as well as a devoted father, and math/social studies teacher. He grew up with boxing, sharing an interest with his father from an early age. He has been involved in sports for over twenty years, with a focus in sport management for the last seven. He received his BA in History from Wesley College in 2002 and currently is pursuing a Masters Degree in Sports Management from California University of Pennsylvania.  

Douglas Purnell - Mr. Purnell works as a formulation chemist, and lectures at William Patterson University in New Jersey. He received his BA in Chemistry from Delaware State University in 2010. He has been active in the field for nearly a decade and is currently a Chemistry Doctoral candidate at the New Jersey Institute of Technology.

Nicole Lerner - Mrs. Lerner is a Science Teacher in New Castle, Delaware. After graduating from the University of Delaware, she pursued her career in education through the Delaware Teaching Fellows program. She earned her Masters in Special Education from Wilmington University and has been applying her skills in the classroom ever since. A cutting edge educator, Nicole worked on the state level implementing new science standards and programs across Delaware.
story_txt:
What is SpyBox?
 
I'm Johnny Woods Jr., and I'm a father, teacher, student and an extreme boxing fan. Like me, many fans have memories tied to great fights, and fighters. The recent rise of mixed martial arts, and the ever-growing suspicion of greed and corruption in boxing have caused many fans to develop a love/hate relationship with the sport. They love the sport, but hate pay-per-views and politics. SpyBox was born out of fan frustration; the frustration over politics, promoters, and a pay-per-view system that far too often results in fans, and fighters, never seeing the match-ups they want, and/or when they want them. The SpyBox vision lies in changing where, how and when fans view fights so that we will be able to see great fights more regularly for free, and not at the whims of pay-per-view or premium cable channels. What We Need This campaign will help us accomplish five things:1) Build a user friendly website dedicated to live streaming.2) Purchase HD Cameras and equipment necessary for live streaming events.3) Secure rights to classic fight footage for the online archive.4) Initial staffing of our production team. 5) Travel expenses for the production team covering live events.Check out our perks and choose the one(s), that make you smile and feel free to share our campaign by clicking on the Facebook and Twitter links.  Our Impact IMAGINENO pay per view fightsandseeing the fights you want when fighters are in their prime.For years fighters and the sport of boxing have fought a reputation for corruption and greed. Right now an opportunity exists to flip the pay per view structure, taking power away from cable providers, promoters, and pay per view distributors. story:
The Concept

The Kenosha Creative Space will be a self-sustaining community center/ makerspace that will enhance the creative economy in downtown Kenosha and add to the overall economic and cultural vitality of Kenosha’s downtown and the region. 

Close to the I-94 corridor, in close proximity to both Chicago and Milwaukee, home to three post-secondary institutions and located by Lake Michigan, Kenosha is the ideal location for a creative hub for artists and creative entrepreneurs looking to start a business, incubate a project or protoype a product.

A Community-Initiated-Development

The Kenosha Creative Space  is a team project with participation from the City of Kenosha,  the Kenosha Art Association, ExposeKenosha as project manager and the Kenosha Community Foundation as fiscal sponsor and lead fundraising partner. The project is focused on the rehabilitation and re-purposing of a blighted building located at 5722-6th Avenue in downtown Kenosha, into a space to be used as a combined community center, makerspace and business incubator for creatives.

The revitalization of this former Kresge Department Store building into the Kenosha Creative Space conforms to the developmental strategies adopted by the City of Kenosha in the 2012 Downtown Kenosha Strategic Development Plan.



Commitment to Community

The Kenosha Creative Space is committed to creating economic opportunities for local artists, musicians, creatives, entrepreneurs and their local partner organizations. The partner organizations and individual members share the goal of using their collective resources for the mutual benefit of the Kenosha Creative Space, the creative community and the community-at-large.


How we will use the money?

The Kenosha Creative Space needs to fundraise $103,000 in matching funds the City of Kenosha Community Development Block Grant (CDBG) that will allows to complete the rehabilitation of the building. The $33,000 to be raised by the Indie-Go-Go campaign will be used not only as part of the CDBG matching funds, but also to complete structural repairs, including plumbing and electrical upgrades on the building. We have been working with community organizations and now we are asking for your assistance to help us complete our goal.


What will you get?

  • To get started, you will earn the bragging rights. You are helping and supporting the Kenosha Creative Community.
  • Followed by A HUGE Thank you! from everyone at the Kenosha Creative Space, Thank you, Thank you, Thank You!
  • In addition to the perks you select with your contribution, our fundraiser partner the Kenosha Community Foundation is a 501(c)(3) public charity; all of your contribution are tax deductible.


How else can you help us?

Join us in our mission to transform an empty space into a creative hub,  Tell everybody you know about the Kenosha Creative Space - share, like, tweet, blog, spread the word about our project in any way you can. It costs you $.00 but it will have a big impact on our Kenosha community!


And If you have any additional questions:

Please contact us at info@KenoshaCreativeSpace.com


"As the creative community becomes more important to Kenosha’s economic and cultural development, artists, makers and creatives require a place of their own to gather and exchange ideas."

The Kenosha Creative Space is that place.

story:
About Us

Dan and Reid have known each other since the 3rd grade.  Growing up in a small town in Connecticut, they have remained best friends since leaving for college and following their own career paths.  Through My Lens is a passion project for both Dan and Reid, as they look to combine their respective talents to reach as many students as possible.  

Meet Reid

Reid Davenport is an award-winning documentarian who has made numerous films featuring people with disabilities. As a person with a disability himself, he is interested in portraying this overlooked perspective. His films have been shown across the country and around the world, and have gained prominent media attention from NPR, BBC and the Washington Post. He received a Master of Fine Arts in Documentary Film & Video from Stanford University in 2016.

Meet Dan

Daniel Lee is a disability advocate and has been volunteering for organizations since middle school. He has worked with various groups and clubs including Bridges and Greater Waltham ARC. He received his Bachelor’s Degree in Economics and Business from Brandeis University. Currently, he works as a Risk Examiner for the Federal Deposit Insurance Corporation.

Filmmakers

If you think you have an idea of a video or already have made a video that is relevant to our cause, let us know so we can promote it!  

From a school or university?  

Please reach out if you're interested in having us come to talk to your students! 

Stay Up to Date and Contact

throughmylens.us
@throughmylensus
facebook.com/throughmylensus

reid@throughmylens.us
dan@throughmylens.us

story:
Who Are We?

About four of us started this project in the summer of 2015, we now have an engineering team in both California and China. We developed the framework of what we called Smart Recognition and Prediction data engine on cloud side. Then we decided to design our own consumer-side devices to, first, personalize our concept of ubiquitous smartness, bring joys of the experience to consumers, and second, to ensure the data of integrity feeding our server, so we will have real "big data". We did it with angel funding, and completed prototypes of two devices and the back-end server. Our team is now ready for the next step, turn prototypes into final products and services. 

What Are The Products & Use Cases?

There are initially three devices, uBOT (personal robot), uSEE (smart screen) and uKNOW (sensor). They interact with one another. Two of them will interact with users, and will communicate with our cloud server, the Smart Engine. 

Use Case 1

In a typical weekday morning, I go down to my dining room. I sit down and prepare to eat, and then uBOT, sitting on the kitchen counter, turns over to me. Right after uBOT greets me, uSEE stops what it is displaying of black and white, Manhattan street view (my favorite photos), and start showing date, time, city name (where I live), and weather condition, Five seconds later, the screen switches to show headline news (the types of what I care). Five seconds later, it switches again to show my calendar (today I have 2 meetings at 10am and 2:30pm each, and it's the deadline for my project first draft). In another five seconds, the screen switches to show traffic condition of my normal route driving to work (the heavy traffic part). Last, a screen shows my "Today's health index", 8 on the scale of 10 (10 being the best). Then the screen resumes its "digital photo frame", showing my favorite photos which rotate every 10 seconds. Note that the whole process I have no manual operation of any sort. AND, the photos on uSEE's screen are all my personal favorite pictures, stored at uSEE.

My son Ethan comes to dining table now. uBOT greets Ethan, and then uSEE starts to show his favorite game. He's at Pokemon level 12, then reminds him of his social-study home work submission. 

The above repeats when my wife Kathy shows up, as to showing her route to work traffic, her calendar, and her health index. 

Use Case 2

One minute after everyone has left home, uBOT enters "surveillance mode". Under this mode, uBOT's "head" (upper body) will rotate 360° in every 1 minute slot at low rotating speed. 

Imagine that front door (or one of windows) is suddenly opened. If uBOT can directly sees the door, it immediately turns over its front HD camera toward the door, captures the person, and triggers "alert mode". If uBOT can't directly see the door, but a uSEE can, the system triggers "alert mode", too. uBOT and uSEE (herein refer to as the system) will then do two things: 1) in real time, family members' phones will receive a courtesy message, informing the door was opened. 2) The system waits to identify the person(s) who enters the door (such identification will depend on the number of factors to complete. If interested, we can discuss offline). If identified as a member of the family, for instance, Ethan comes home from school, alert is dismissed. If identified as a "stranger", a second message is sent to family members' phones immediately. 

Every family member will receive an alert or a dismiss message (the second message). Members can touch a link contained in the message, then access uBOT's camera and watch the situation remotely. In the message there is police number to call with a single touch. Family members' phone numbers are also showing in the message, calling son or daughter telling them not to go home at this moment, with a single touch. 

As a service the system can also allow family members to access video taken by uBOT and/or uSEE afterwards, which is stored at server, as a fee-based service (optional). As far as the service is not subscribed, there is no fee of any sort charged to users. 

Use Case 3

When you're talking in a video call (limited to two parties), and you move to the position that is within the distance of 6.5 Ft. (2 meters, tentatively) from a uSEE unit (let's call it DDU 1, digital display unit 1), in the front position, your phone will begin to mirror its screen to DDU 1 (with a pop-up button for you to touch, if you press it you give permission for the mirroring). With a single touch, mirroring starts. At that point you will talk to the uSEE screen and can put your phone into your packet. Then you leave DDU 1, and get close to DDU 2. DDU 1 stops mirroring and DDU 2 takes over mirroring (2nd DDU will not ask for permission). At this point, you are continuing talking to DDU2. This feature gives convenience to users to be able to move around doing chores or looking for something, while talking on the video call without being interrupted. 

The same procedure will take place when you are watching a movie on your Smart phone and start walking around. You simply walk to any uSEE DDU and continue watching the movie. 

On a side explanation, when you are not using your Smart phone, there is no Mirroring or Mirroring Transfer triggered. uSEE DDUs are just like digital photo frames, and rotate to display the photos stored in the uSEE. However, they are "Smart" digital frames. After the machines work in your home for a few days, uSEEs (in fact the system including uBOT and server) will learn what's your taste of a picture. So when you are nearby a uSEE DDU, it will show pictures of your type. When your son or daughter is nearby, uSEE screen will shift to show pictures of his type. Yes, you will need to store pictures in all uSEE units. 

Remember that uSEE and uBOT are both powerful robots, except that uSEE can't move. When a uSEE sees someone, the whole system at home, including uBOT and other uSEEs, all see you. In other words, any of the uBOT or uSEE at home identifies a stranger, they will not perform Mirroring and Mirroring Transfer. Rather they will do nothing when there are family members at home, or trigger an alarm message if the system is at "surveillance mode", as described in previous use cases. 

More Use Cases

uBOT and uSEE are an open platform from hardware standpoint. By offering what are described in the use case 1, 2 and 3, it does not limit what it can do from a long term. Users can download more apps from Unseen Motion website or app stores, then uBOT and uSEE can do more things, after purchased. We plan to add more smart devices down the road, such as a sensor for examining allergen, for ensuring garage door is closed, for watching your weight and exercise amount, etc. All you need to do is watch notification message from the screen, and download and install new apps on uBOT and uSEE. That's it.  

Our Mission

The concepts like cloud, big data, machine learning is all abstract. We have found our way to bring the smartness directly to consumers, and help everyone raise awareness of his or her well being and that of their love ones. Our devices are Personal Robots. Once you have them in home, over the time you will build a personal relationship with them like another brother or sister. And, the intelligence should definitely not be contained by a single box. It must be everywhere, anytime, when one wants it. With the achievement we have got thus far, we are confident that we will make the dream come true. So, help us by contributing to this project. You will not be disappointed!

story:
NATEC project

SuDHiCA (Sustainable Development for Highland Communities Association) is a community based organization based in the rural highland communities of northern Laos and our work is centered around helping rural communities in Laos grow! We are in the process of building an education and training center that teaches rural farmers how to do agribusiness in a way that is environmentally friendly and doesn't harm the rich biodiversity of Laos.

We will provide workshops and hands on education to local Khmu villagers on performing eco-friendly farming without the use of shifting cultivation and herbicides that further damage their environment. The NATEC project will also give rural families a source of economic income, food security, and the opportunity to better their livelihoods.


Background of Laos

The Lao People’s Democratic Republic is one of the least developed nations in the world. It is very mountainous and has no direct access to any seaports. Most of the country is still inaccessible by road or roads can be severely damaged by natural disasters like mudslides or flooding. To make matters worse, much of the country faces problems with food security. Rural highland communities and ethnic villages face even much higher rates of food insecurity than the rest of Laos. “One in two children five years of age and below face stunted growth or is chronically malnourished. Ethnic highland communities living in remote areas and rural children are particularly vulnerable to food insecurity and malnourishment”.


Khmu Culture

Ethnic villagers rely heavily upon the highland forests to perform shifting cultivation. Growing rice and other crops is such an essential portion of their culture that they even have prescribed gender roles related to agriculture. Khmu (ethnic tribe) women decide what kinds of rice to plant and Khmu men decide what land to plant the rice upon. They love their land and respect the forest greatly as it is their main source of income, clothing, and food. Khmu people themselves say “without rice, the Khmu die”. Before planting rice and other crops, the Khmu perform traditional rituals asking permission from the nature spirits to lend the land to them and vowing to return the land back to the spirits upon completion of the harvest. They ask the spirits: “Please give us a good crop of rice, may we have enough to eat our fill”.


Challenges with Shifting Cultivation

Traditionally, the method of  shifting cultivation was quite successful for the Khmu people. However, now they have much larger populations and foraging in the forest for food has lead to a critical loss of biodiversity that is not sustainable and it is no longer eco-friendly. They must use young forests to produce food at the rate that they are consuming it. Young forests are susceptible to increased weed cultivation and thus the locals must use herbicides to kill off the unwanted weeds.


How can you help?

We are asking for your help here at SuDHiCA because in order to make the NATEC project fully functional, we need to build an agro-ecological demonstration and research center. This will serve as the location where we will provide workshops to teach our farmers how to set up their own agribusiness plan to provide food security to their communities and to generate income for impoverished families.

Your contribution will go towards increasing the skills of young Khmu farmers in agroecological practices, developing individualized agribusiness plans with farmers who join the NATEC project, and creating a source of revenue for farming families to help kick-start their own agribusiness plan.

Your Impact

The contribution that you make will create a tangible difference in this community. By donating to the NATEC project, you are helping to eradicate poverty and malnourishment in the highland communities of Laos. Furthermore, your money is going towards creating a community that cares about their environment around them and farming in a way that is sustainable and doesn't destroy the precious biodiversity of Laos.


Making a Change

SuDHiCA and the NATEC project (Namsing Agroecological Tranining and Education Center) strive to provide comprehensive environmental education and hands-on practice in the field of agroecology so that rural farmers and their families can create an individualized action plan with us that is sustainable and environmentally friendly for their communities. Upon completion of the workshop training with the NATEC project, rural farmers will be able to create a source of economic income for their families in a way that is environmentally conscious and sustainable for the forests and upland rice fields that are so important and precious to their culture.


Preserve Khmu Culture

Collectively, our organization exists to cooperate with the ethnic villagers in a way that preserves their civilization and customs, but also wishes to provide a successful model of environmentally friendly agriculture so that these communities can take control of their livelihoods and decide their own future.


Our Perks

We would love to give every single donor a handicraft made from natural materials locally sourced from Laos highlands. However, it is quite expensive to do any sort of international shipping from Laos. We welcome you to visit our NATEC project upon completion if you ever decide to come to Laos.  We appreciate every donation and your name will be included in a list of donors who helped made the NATEC project become possible to serve the Khmu communities.

Our milestones:

Uncle Khamsao is one of the NATEC project members who is very interested to start his own ecological agribusiness and hope to increase his family's income so that they can have adequate food for family meals and provide financial support for his children to obtain a higher education. He is pictured here practicing new ideas in the project field after he has learned from several workshops with us about ecological vegetable growing by Hugelkultur technique, varieties selection, smart-climate agriculture, natural pest and weed management, plant nutrition, and soil management. We teach them to always care about environmental sustainability; it is the heart of our teaching.  

Khmu children enjoying an environmental awareness activity!

Our eco-toilet model designed by SuDHiCA has been built with all natural materials locally sourced from the NATEC project, it is designed to work with the surrounding ecosystem and it is much less maintenance than a traditional toilet. This eco-toilet model will serve as a great example for villagers who can not afford expensive materials to build their own toilets (most of the rural highland people don't have toilets and have poor hygiene). This sample model will show them alternative options to building a toilet, it is not expensive and it works like a traditional toilet.

We have finished building a demonstration of eco-friendly soil management at the NATEC project, we focus to educate people on what soil is and how vital it is for our crops. At NATEC, we always tell our farmers that 'healthy soil gives you healthy food'. Furthermore, we increase  our farmer's knowledge about the connection between ecology and agriculture.

Vanxai (SuDHiCA's agricultural technical staff) and uncle Bounnoi (SuDHiCA's field staff) are doing research and an experiment on a seed bomb technique that will help farmers to acquire new skills and serve as a good alternative option to seeding with much less work. 

Sengla and Buachan  are our role model family for the NATEC project who focus on fruit and herb ecological farming. They started to work and get support from us since March of this year, they are just like other rural families living in the rural highlands of Laos that hope to earn more income to improve their living conditions. By starting their own agribusiness, it ensures food security to help build a better future for their children and create stable employment in their homeland. They expect to get their first big sale of their produce in November of this year!

Some of the NATEC's family members can grow their own vegetables to supply their kitchens and increase the nutrition of the meals which they feed to their  children. Now, they do not need to forage through the forest for hours to collect their food.

Visit our Facebook page!

Learn more about our organization SuDHiCA

Thank you from SuDHiCA Staff and Volunteers!


Thank you from Pakhuaynyang Villagers!
story_txt:
NATEC project
SuDHiCA (Sustainable Development for Highland Communities Association) is a community based organization based in the rural highland communities of northern Laos and our work is centered around helping rural communities in Laos grow! We
are in the process of building an education and training center that teaches
rural farmers how to do agribusiness in a way that is environmentally friendly
and doesn't harm the rich biodiversity of Laos.
We
will provide workshops and hands on education to local Khmu villagers on
performing eco-friendly farming without the use of shifting cultivation and
herbicides that further damage their environment. The NATEC project will also
give rural families a source of economic income, food security, and the
opportunity to better their livelihoods.





Background of Laos



The Lao People’s Democratic Republic is one of the least developed nations in the world. It is very mountainous and has no direct access to any seaports. Most of the country is still inaccessible by road or roads can be severely damaged by natural disasters like mudslides or flooding. To make matters worse, much of the country faces problems with food security. Rural highland communities and ethnic villages face even much higher rates of food insecurity than the rest of Laos. “One in two children five years of age and below face stunted growth or is chronically malnourished. Ethnic highland communities living in remote areas and rural children are particularly vulnerable to food insecurity and malnourishment”.




Khmu Culture
Ethnic villagers rely heavily upon the highland forests to perform shifting cultivation. Growing rice and other crops is such an essential portion of their culture that they even have prescribed gender roles related to agriculture. Khmu (ethnic tribe) women decide what kinds of rice to plant and Khmu men decide what land to plant the rice upon. They love their land and respect the forest greatly as it is their main source of income, clothing, and food. Khmu people themselves say “without rice, the Khmu die”. Before planting rice and other crops, the Khmu perform traditional rituals asking permission from the nature spirits to lend the land to them and vowing to return the land back to the spirits upon completion of the harvest. They ask the spirits: “Please give us a good crop of rice, may we have enough to eat our fill”.



Challenges with Shifting Cultivation
Traditionally,
the method of  shifting cultivation was quite successful for the Khmu
people. However, now they have much larger populations and foraging in the
forest for food has lead to a critical loss of biodiversity that is not
sustainable and it is no longer eco-friendly. They must use young forests to
produce food at the rate that they are consuming it. Young forests are
susceptible to increased weed cultivation and thus the locals must use
herbicides to kill off the unwanted weeds.



How can you help?
We
are asking for your help here at SuDHiCA because in order to make the NATEC
project fully functional, we need to build an agro-ecological demonstration and
research center. This will serve as the location where we will provide
workshops to teach our farmers how to set up their own agribusiness plan to
provide food security to their communities and to generate income for
impoverished families.
Your
contribution will go towards increasing the skills of young Khmu farmers in
agroecological practices, developing individualized agribusiness plans with
farmers who join the NATEC project, and creating a source of revenue for
farming families to help kick-start their own agribusiness plan.





Your Impact
The
contribution that you make will create a tangible difference in this community.
By donating to the NATEC project, you are helping to eradicate poverty and
malnourishment in the highland communities of Laos. Furthermore, your money is
going towards creating a community that cares about their environment around
them and farming in a way that is sustainable and doesn't destroy the precious
biodiversity of Laos.



Making a Change
SuDHiCA and the NATEC project (Namsing
Agroecological Tranining and Education Center) strive to provide comprehensive
environmental education and hands-on practice in the field of agroecology so
that rural farmers and their families can create an individualized action plan
with us that is sustainable and environmentally friendly for their communities.
Upon completion of the workshop training with the NATEC project, rural farmers
will be able to create a source of economic income for their families in a way
that is environmentally conscious and sustainable for the forests and upland
rice fields that are so important and precious to their culture.




Preserve Khmu Culture

Collectively, our organization exists to cooperate with the ethnic villagers in a way that preserves their civilization and customs, but also wishes to provide a successful model of environmentally friendly agriculture so that these communities can take control of their livelihoods and decide their own future.


Our Perks
We would love to give every single donor a handicraft made from natural materials locally sourced from Laos highlands. However, it is quite expensive to do any sort of international shipping from Laos. We welcome you to visit our NATEC project upon completion if you ever decide to come to Laos.  We appreciate every donation and your name will be included in a list of donors who helped made the NATEC project become possible to serve the Khmu communities.

Our milestones:


Uncle Khamsao is one of the NATEC project members who is very interested to start his own ecological agribusiness and hope to increase his family's income so that they can have adequate food for family meals and provide financial support for his children to obtain a higher education. He is pictured here practicing new ideas in the project field after he has learned from several workshops with us about ecological vegetable growing by Hugelkultur technique, varieties selection, smart-climate agriculture, natural pest and weed management, plant nutrition, and soil management. We teach them to always care about environmental sustainability; it is the heart of our teaching.  

Khmu children enjoying an environmental awareness activity!

Our eco-toilet model designed by SuDHiCA has been built with all natural materials locally sourced from the NATEC project, it is designed to work with the surrounding ecosystem and it is much less maintenance than a traditional toilet. This eco-toilet model will serve as a great example for villagers who can not afford expensive materials to build their own toilets (most of the rural highland people don't have toilets and have poor hygiene). This sample model will show them alternative options to building a toilet, it is not expensive and it works like a traditional toilet.

We have finished building a demonstration of eco-friendly soil management at the NATEC project, we focus to educate people on what soil is and how vital it is for our crops. At NATEC, we always tell our farmers that 'healthy soil gives you healthy food'. Furthermore, we increase  our farmer's knowledge about the connection between ecology and agriculture.

Vanxai (SuDHiCA's agricultural technical staff) and uncle Bounnoi (SuDHiCA's field staff) are doing research and an experiment on a seed bomb technique that will help farmers to acquire new skills and serve as a good alternative option to seeding with much less work. 

Sengla and Buachan  are our role model family for the NATEC project who focus on fruit and herb ecological farming. They started to work and get support from us since March of this year, they are just like other rural families living in the rural highlands of Laos that hope to earn more income to improve their living conditions. By starting their own agribusiness, it ensures food security to help build a better future for their children and create stable employment in their homeland. They expect to get their first big sale of their produce in November of this year!


Some of the NATEC's family members can grow their own vegetables to supply their kitchens and increase the nutrition of the meals which they feed to their  children. Now, they do not need to forage through the forest for hours to collect their food.

story:
Short Summary

St Louis Jewish Parents magazine was created in order to fill the void for parents between blogs and statistics-heavy academic articles.  From my kitchen table, this has been a labor of love and I have been honored to provide this resource to our families and local businesses in this great city of St. Louis. 

We are providing a magazine that our children, parents, and grandparents can benefit from, contribute to, and can be proud of. However, I need your help.

 While the ad sales continue to climb significantly, and the local businesses are seeing tremendous benefit from the advertising, we still need your help in two critical ways:

1) Funding is needed to cover the start-up costs of printing and the graphic design artist until the ad contracts and payments come in.

2) Recruitment of the advertising team, which benefits both the magazine's production and provides employment opportunities for our community.

I cannot continue putting monthly magazine expenses on credit cards and I need to begin paying down on the charges from the first few months when I did not have ad income.  In order to do this and be able to pay for the next 4 months worth of production costs, I need to raise $30,000 by September 18th, and optimally $100,000 total.

Ways You Can Help

We understand that for some people contributing financially is difficult, but that doesn't mean you can't make a huge difference to the magazine in this challenging time.

How you can help:

1) Please get the word out and tell others that you support the magazine and this campaign. You can use the Indiegogo share tools to easily tell your friends about it.

2) Think about who you know in this community - can they support this campaign? Do they have a company who could advertise in or sponsor the magazine? 

3) Do you have friends who like to sell? Ask them to send me a resume.

I welcome your questions!  If there is anything else I can tell you, please email me at stephanie.berk@stlouisjewishparents.com.

 

The Facts:

- There are now 18 issues of St Louis Jewish Parents that have been distributed.

-Local photographers, e.g. Yana Hotter and Shana Watkins have contributed their time and talent. 

- My husband and I have personally fronted the bulk of the costs; approximately $90,000 in lieu of asking investors to fund a brand new social entrepreneurship project, created to benefit the local community. To date, I have not received any income from the magazine.

- Full 6 month intervals of ad sales:  

          - 1/1/15- 6/30/15       $5,860 in ad sales

          - 7/1/15- 12/31/15      $27,392 in ad sales

         - 1/1/16- 6/30/16         $41,971 in ad sales

 - Magazine's monthly minimum cost: $12,000 per month. As seen above, our growth has been significant and will continue to climb, making the magazine self-sustained by January 2017. The purpose of this campaign is to pay off existing start-up costs and bridge the monetary gap between now and January.

With your help, we can create the monetary bridge that is needed as we go from my family's personally backing the magazine to it being entirely supported by our wonderful, local businesses. 


In order to show how appreciative I am for the support, we are offering numerous perks, such as tickets to sporting events, tours of a laboratory, gift cards, and much more! 


The Impact

When I consider the impact that this magazine is having on our Jewish community, I think about the 7 year old girl who learned how to talk to adults about the classmates who were bullying her, the teenage boy who now has a meaningful piece of writing to include in his college application, the overwhelmed new mother who found a free Mommy and Me group to bring her baby to, and she met other overwhelmed new moms, and the 98 year old grandmother who had a meaningful conversation with her daughter about one of the child development articles. I have personally been told dozens of such stories and every time I hear one, it validates the purpose of this magazine and inspires me to continue.

From the Jewish perspective, we are engaging with ALL denominations of Jewish people in St. Louis, regardless of shul affiliation or Hebrew/Jewish day school attendance. Our magazine is being read by families with Jewish parents, interfaith families and even non-Jewish families who want to learn more about their neighbors (which is amazing!), who love our content and can't find anything similar elsewhere. We are reaching a HUGE audience and providing them with valuable information about Jewish life, in a welcoming, inclusive manner. Every month, readers have Jewish holidays explained, learn from our locals rabbis in the Rabbi to Parent article, receive easy and delicious Kosher recipes, receive a calendar with Jewish activities included, and much more - all in a "non-pressured" and "non-judgmental" way.

From the child development perspective, we consistently offer research-based articles in child development written by experts with MDs or PhDs for children ranging from newborn babies to teens. The "From the Doctor" article features a different local specialist each issue, on a subject requested by a St. Louis parent, and is a much safer alternative to consulting strangers on social media or anecdotal parenting blogs. And our "Oops, Bad Parent" section lets us all share in the humorous side of parenting! (My personal favorite is "Oops, I spent 45 minutes rocking my baby to sleep only to wake him up when I accidentally dropped my iPhone on him".)

We are providing local kids and parents with writing opportunities that simply didn't exist before. (One 14 year old boy learned that he loved writing when it was a topic that he himself chose.  He also learned from the feedback we provided, how careful he needs to be when he puts certain things on paper, especially to 10,000 people, many of whom are strangers.)

The track record over the past year and a half shows that the magazine adapts to the needs and is responsive to our St. Louis community. Here is a small sampling of some of the wonderful feedback I have received over the past 18 months:

- Teacher of 4th grade and mother of 2: "Look at how amazing this is!  We put the magazines in their book bags, but they all took them out to read them while they are waiting at carpool line.  They are actually READING  and discussing articles, and doing the Games page together!"

- Mother of 2 teen boys: "I never expected my guys to pick up a magazine.  But when we were driving to school, one of them told me that I should read the article on Internet Safety and Independence because he read it, and it was good."

- Grandmother: "I always pick up the magazine.  I read it first, and then give it to my daughter. I feel that I am more current with parenting after I read it."

- Office Manager and Aunt: "Stephanie, I am not Jewish, but I love your magazine.  My niece is having a problem with spitting up.  Can you have an article about that in babies?"

- Dad and Physician: "I bring the magazine that my child brings home from religious school to work with me on Monday.  I read it and share it with my colleagues at the hospital."

- Email from a reader: "Thank you so much.  I had to take my child to the emergency room, and I felt so much better when I saw your magazine was in the waiting room."

In summary, this magazine is not just valuable to parents, grandparents, and caregivers, it is invaluable. We are providing a much-needed and utilized resource to the community, while at the same time providing employment opportunities (ad sales, delivery drivers, etc) and boosting the success of our local businesses.

I want nothing more than to be able to continue to publish this magazine for you. I thank you, from the bottom of my heart, for supporting this magazine for the past 18 months, and I hope you will consider providing your financial support to bridge the monetary gap between now and the end of December, when the ad revenue will finally sustain the magazine independently.
